19542: Fresh Volunteers.author: Kirbster
19542: Fresh Volunteers.text_parsed: Steadfast Guard was running around in the same set, so the volunteers may appear outclassed in a white rebel deck. However... keep in mind this was Masques block, where every competitive tourney deck was running a set of Rishadan Port (and likely a lone Kor Haven, too, in white decks.) The Guard, meanwhile, required double white. That means the volunteers were actually much more likely to come out on turn two if you drew them! Being able to keep your opponent mana-locked was much more useful than a vigilant 2/2, so it was a likely trade-off.

19546: Inviolability.author: Calver
19546: Inviolability.text_parsed:
Yeah, there are quite a few "invincibility" combos you could use, but it should be mentioned that this card also works wonders protecting fatties or pumping Deathtouch and Venom creatures.

Just throwing it on any deathtouch/basilisk turns a 1-time creature trade into a fullblown deterrent. Sure, the creature can get 2-for-1'd, but if you manage to take even one of your opponent's creatures out before he draws his removal then you've broken even. Even if you don't take out a creature but made him skip a combat step that's worth the one card you played anyway (it's the same thing as a fog).

Drop it on a fatty and your opponent has no choice but use nondamage removal. He can't chump and bolt it, he can't kill it with a bigger creature, and he can't deathtouch it.

Of course he can remove the enchantment, but that isn't detrimental at all. His spell (probably) cost him 2 mana and a card and this costs 2 mana and a card. It's an even trade of both tempo and card advantage.

someone help with rulings on this:
If i toss this on a creature (let's say Aura Gnarlid) in response to removal, will it survive and then be protected against (hopefully) my opponent's deck?
Example, lets say he tries to Doom Blade my Gnarlid, can I play this in response and be forever exempt from his black removal?
(Unless he plays something else in response, or targets the aura directly)

edit: yes.

19551: Cho-Manno's Blessing.author: RaymondKHessel
19551: Cho-Manno's Blessing.text_parsed: Masques Block had some great mechanics to it, and playing creature enchantments at instant speed opened up tons of opportunities. It's been pointed out by other comments that this (like Alexi's Cloak) can operate as a counterspell when played in response to your opponent's spell. Then it sticks around and offers all that goodness that comes with color protection. In Block play, a Steadfast Guard with a Cho-Manno's Blessing pro-blue was a win condition against Rising Waters. Playing Rebels with one of these in your hand is a very comforting feeling when your opponent is looking to torch your weak recruiters.

19555: Righteous Aura.author: yyukichigai
19555: Righteous Aura.text_parsed:
I remember getting a bunch of these out of Visions boosters, looking at them and going "why wouldn't I just use a Circle of Protection? Who wants to pay 2 life to prevent damage when I could just prevent it all?"

Yeah, I was pretty dumb back then. This card has saved me so many times I've lost count. Prevent all damage from ANY source, not just of a specific color/etc. like Story Circle. The uses are innumerable.

Good to use alongside Story Circle, I suppose. Between the two you should have all your bases covered.

19557: Waterfront Bouncer.author: non1337
19557: Waterfront Bouncer.text_parsed: This card always have been extremely strong. It stops many combos and mana acceleration, and I've exploited comes into play effects of Scrivener to reclaim counterspell myself. It is very cruel as the win condition of that deck involves a discard engine, kill enemy creatures by sending them back to their hand and force them to discard, while cleaning the opponent's field with Recoil, Glowing Anemone and Rishadan Cutpurse. Enemy permanents are taken down one by one while I'm protected by a counterspell at hand. Opponent only lose when they have no permanents and no cards in hand, with my Saprazzan Outrigger as finisher.

19557: Waterfront Bouncer.author: The_Murderauder
19557: Waterfront Bouncer.text_parsed:
The most embarrassing 1/2 creatures that beat this guy up and live to tell the tale?

Well, in no particular order,

Squire, an awkward teenager,
Dwarven Lieutenant, a 3-foot man,
Cinder Crawler, a lizard,
Kobold Drill Sergeant, a kobold,
Lambholt Elder, an old lady,
Basilica Screecher, a regular-sized, non-vampire bat,
Benevolent Unicorn, exactly what it sounds like,
Courier Hawk, essentially a messenger pigeon,
Xira Arien, an insectoid cosplayer,
Sanctuary Cat, for obvious reasons,
Academy Rector, an old man,
Port Inspector, another old man, and probably his boss,
and of course, both the infamous Storm Crow and Chimney Imp.

My personal favorite? Willow Faerie, a half-naked, six-inch woman.

And that's not even counting all the other 1/X P/T creatures in the game.

But hey, at least he can take down that Goldenglow Moth, even if it does take everything he can muster.

19559: Darting Merfolk.author: Salient

This, Aluren, Merrow Reejerey and an Island gets you infinite Storm for a lethal Brain Freeze, which is my favorite answer to the question "WTF, why did you splash green in a Merfolk deck?"

(In mono-blue you need to abuse double-High Tide to ensure the Island that Reejerey keeps untapping nets you the you need. A more viable "go infinite" option is Æther Vial set to 2, but that doesn't generate Storm, so you have to abuse Intruder Alarm or something...)

Only real combo that seems actually worthwhile off hand to me; this guy and Nemesis Mask.

19566: Rishadan Cutpurse.author: N03y3D33R
19566: Rishadan Cutpurse.text_parsed:
Here's an idea of how she ran in Masques:

T1 You drop your cloud sprite. End Turn.

Your opponent drops their land and passes.

T2 You hoodwink their land and swing for 1 with your sprite.

They play the same land again and pass because they can't play anything.

T3 You play War Tax and swing with your sprite again.

They drop a land and cast their two drop creature and pass.

T4 You drop Cutpurse and they either sac the creature or sac one of their lands out of desperation.

From there on in you can just drop Rishadan Ports and more hoodwinks and slowly whittle them down with your smaller drops. If they do get a threat out, just use war tax and it becomes unable to attack.

19570: Counterspell.author: TDL
19570: Counterspell.text_parsed: Ah, Counterspell. How I loved you, and yet I still understand why you had to go. If you were still around, the cries of "Blue is OP!!!1!" from the newbies would be even louder, and (slightly) more justified. 19571: Brainstorm.author: DarthParallax
19571: Brainstorm.text_parsed:
Actually, LeoKula, No. The Izzet vs. Golgari Brainstorm is easily the 'best'- it's the truest to flavor, the flavor does call for that different, less classic more modern art style, and in fact it reveals better than any print that, from a flavor perspective, Brainstorm is more Blue-Red than Blue-White. It's "Stormy" -and- "Brainy", like Jimmy Neutron "Brain Blast!"

It works very well with their flavor of Science-o-mancy. That over-sized one for Worlds looks a bit too much like Parallax or Galactus would if you made a movie that sucked. I will grant, though, that the Izzet card is also 'too Red'.

But Brainstorm has become one of the Most Iconic Blue Spells in the game. Because it is SO significantly ingrained to the color on a number of levels at this point, it deserves a more mono-colored artwork than the Izzet mage one. Even if that is slightly antithetical to the real concept of Brainstorm. (A Jimmy Neutron-like Brain blast).

Saprazzan Vizier is a more meditative, contemplative, reactive not proactive, Brainstorm.

Forgetting the Power 9 (which is weird because the Power 9 are responsible for making Blue what it became.) there are maybe 10 cards that SCREAM "BLUE". The bluest blue you've ever seen. Bluer than that. BLUER. Look, We're talking Andalites-look-Green, Obi-Wan's lightsaber-looks-Red by comparison Blue. It was BLUE. They are:

Polar Kraken
Mystical Tutor
Force of Will
Counterspell
Brainstorm
Tarmogoyf (I jest)
Cryptic Command
Jace, the Mind Sculptor

Jace is a monster of BLUE-ness, looking like all of the others put together. (Including Money-goyf) Well, cuz that's what he is. Jace's art looks almost Black though, in a "Darth Jace, excecute Order 66" kind of way. Mystical Tutor looks debatably White, like she's a government official or something. She looks chained to that room, not freely adventuring to find more Magic. Force of Will looks like the Hulk. That leaves, really, only Brainstorm as a card to Symbolize Blue, that is really completely original, since much of the newer artwork is calling back to established themes from old artworks.


I will give you THIS- this Brainstorm isthe Blue-est Art in the Game, even if it's not the Brainstorm-est.

1. It's the Vintage print of the card- and Blue is the Color Vintage, Legacy, and Winning.

2. It's one of the most-played cards, and this art probably the most-played art, in its color.

3. Saprazzan Vizier, who has never had a card of herself, is probably the most recognizable character without a creature card in the game.

Vizier > Mystical Tutor. Both artworks are Iconic, and Very Fine, but something tells me that Mystical Tutor is harder to pick out in a cosplay crowd: http://www.gatheringmagic.com/inside-the-deck-las-vegas-video-06272013-videos-from-grand-prix-las-vegas-part-two/

4. Saprazzan Vizier is ALSO the most influential card on Jace, The Mind Sculptor's artwork. Saprazzan Vizier casting Cryptic Command is in fact, basically a Jace, the Mind Sculptor.

And those are all things the Izzet card will never get to say.

In the case of Brainstorm, we will yield to Spike instead of Vorthos for artwork. It's an enigma how one does that, but if you Brainstorm hard enough, you'll find the answer.

19576: Diplomatic Immunity.author: DoctorKenneth
19576: Diplomatic Immunity.text_parsed:
Necromancer's Assistant: Master! I've been spotted at the Bluge Mage's encampment! There's some horrible tendriled monster after -- oh no! It's here! Master, it's here!
Black Mage: Don't worry, I'll banish it back to the depths of--
Tidal Kraken: I wouldn't do that.
Black Mage: What?
Tidal Kraken: I wouldn't do that. I'm an ambassador from Atlantis, and because of the cultural differences, I'm excused from my transgressions. I have diplomatic immunity. In my culture, for instance, it is perfectly acceptable to eat people. Now, are you going to respect my beliefs?
Black Mage: I...I don't think that's a reasonable request.
Tidal Kraken: I swear to the Gods, I'll take this right to the Atlantian embassy.
Black Mage: Fine, fine. Go about your buisness. First it's sword-weilding ectoplasms, now this.
Necromancer's Assistant: Master! Master! It's EATING me!
Black Mage: Oh, you were doomed anyway. Get over it.

MasturbatorDebater: No it wouldn't, actually. Enchantments that are already on the creature don't target them when their effects kick in, so Followed Footsteps should keep making tokens without any trouble.

Quang: How is it better? Canopy Cover can be easily removed by something as simple and cheap as a Naturalize or Demystify. Diplomatic Immunity can't be targeted, so your opponents are going to have to use a nuke-all-Enchantments effect to get rid of it, and if they have their own enchantments, I doubt they'd want to do that.

19576: Diplomatic Immunity.author: Aburaishi
19576: Diplomatic Immunity.text_parsed:
@MasturbatorDebater: No. Shroud simply says it can't be targeted by spells or abilities. It can still be affected by spells or abilities which had already targeted it. It had been targeted by that enchantment prior to being enchanted by this one, so this card has no effect on that one. Otherwise, this card would cancel out its own effect, and that just wouldn't make any sense.

@RedArcher: I'm just checking, but you do realize that the copied creatures don't gain the effects of the enchantments attached to the original, right? Otherwise, Followed Footsteps would be ridiculous, as each copy would copy itself every turn, and you would gain an exponential number each upkeep.
If, on the other hand, you were just creating a combo wherein the opponent can't get rid of the original, which means you keep getting a copy every turn regardless of any attempted removal they have, that is perfectly viable, and quite effective when used on the right creature.

As for using it on Platinum Angel, I hate you. I suddenly feel like I don't have enough board-clearers (see Planar Cleansing) in my deck...

19578: Bog Witch.author: WhiteWizard42
19578: Bog Witch.text_parsed:
glowsticktm: "I was using this card in a deck idea that played cards that had Madness costs where they could be played for an alternate card if they would be discarded. I was just wondering if the card discarded for this ability could be played with the mana produced by the ability."

702.33a Madness is a keyword that represents two abilities. The first is a static ability that functions while the card with madness is in a player’s hand. The second is a triggered ability that functions when the first ability is applied. “Madness ” means “If a player would discard this card, that player discards it, but may exile it instead of putting it into his or her graveyard” and “When this card is exiled this way, its owner may cast it by paying rather than paying its mana cost. If that player doesn’t, he or she puts this card into his or her graveyard.”

Since Bog Witch's ability is a mana ability, it doesn't use the stack and resolves before the triggered ability for Madness is put on the stack. So yes, you can use the mana it makes to pay for the card you ditched to it.
19578: Bog Witch.text_posted:
glowsticktm: "I was using this card in a deck idea that played cards that had Madness costs where they could be played for an alternate card if they would be discarded. I was just wondering if the card discarded for this ability could be played with the mana produced by the ability."

If that player doesn’t, he or she puts this card into his or her graveyard.”

19580: Cateran Persuader.author: Aaron_Forsythe
19580: Cateran Persuader.text_parsed:
Aaron’s Random Card Comment of the Day #57, 1/13/11

I like mirrors in card design--you know, stuff like White Knight and Black Knight, Incremental Growth and Incremental Blight, Mind Spring and Mind Shatter.

Sometimes, however, the aesthetic desire for mirroring doesn’t translate into equal card power or equally compelling gameplay. Mercenaries versus Rebels in Mercadian Masques are a perfect example of mirroring gone wrong.

Rebels, which search up the mana chain, do everything right. If you resolve a lowly Ramosian Sergeant on turn 1, in the span of a few turns you can be attacking your opponent with anything from a Jhoval Queen to a Chameleon Colossus to a Deranged Hermit (thanks to Skyshroud Poacher), all without ever playing another spell. Rebels defined a format and won a Pro Tour.

Mercenaries did it all backwards. They searched down the mana chain, each one only able to get creatures worse than itself. There is no one-mana Mercenary searcher to compare to Ramosian Sergeant--the earliest searcher you could play was this fellow, Cateran Persuader.

Cateran Persuader is a somewhat-hard-to-cast 2/1 that can search for one-mana Mercenaries. Those are Molting Harpy, Rampart Crawler, Soldier of Fortune, and Mothdust Changeling. A lamer crew you’ll never find. Compare that to his Rebel ánalogue, Ramosian Lieutenant, a 1/2. After four turns of searching once you played a Lieutenant, you might control Lin-Sivvi, Defiant Hero; a Ramosian Sky Marshal; and a Jhovall Queen. After the same four turns of searching after you played the Persuader, you’d have something like three Mothdust Changelings and a Molten Harpy. It’s no wonder Mercenaries never went anywhere. God bless Devon Rule for making them at least somewhat interesting in the Great Designer Search.

The only good thing about Cateran Persuader is that his art is one of the Mercenaries that actually feels like, you know, a mercenary. Just look at Death Charmer, Misshapen Fiend, and Skulking Fugitive and ask yourself, “Who would pay money to these idiots?”
19580: Cateran Persuader.text_posted:
[b]Aaron’s Random Card Comment of the Day #57, 1/13/11[/b]

I like mirrors in card design--you know, stuff like [autocard]White Knight[/autocard] and [autocard]Black Knight[/autocard], [autocard]Incremental Growth[/autocard] and [autocard]Incremental Blight[/autocard], [autocard]Mind Spring[/autocard] and [autocard]Mind Shatter[/autocard].

Sometimes, however, the aesthetic desire for mirroring doesn’t translate into equal card power or equally compelling gameplay. Mercenaries versus Rebels in [i]Mercadian Masques [/i]are a perfect example of mirroring gone wrong.

Rebels, which search up the mana chain, do everything right. If you resolve a lowly [autocard]Ramosian Sergeant[/autocard] on turn 1, in the span of a few turns you can be attacking your opponent with anything from a [autocard]Jhoval Queen[/autocard] to a [autocard]Chameleon Colossus[/autocard] to a [autocard]Deranged Hermit[/autocard] (thanks to [autocard]Skyshroud Poacher[/autocard]), all without ever playing another spell. Rebels defined a format and won a Pro Tour.

Mercenaries did it all backwards. They searched down the mana chain, each one only able to get creatures worse than itself. There is no one-mana Mercenary searcher to compare to [autocard]Ramosian Sergeant[/autocard]--the earliest searcher you could play was this fellow, Cateran Persuader.

Cateran Persuader is a somewhat-hard-to-cast [BB] 2/1 that can search for one-mana Mercenaries. Those are [autocard]Molting Harpy[/autocard], [autocard]Rampart Crawler[/autocard], [autocard]Soldier of Fortune[/autocard], and [autocard]Mothdust Changeling[/autocard]. A lamer crew you’ll never find. Compare that to his Rebel ánalogue, [autocard]Ramosian Lieutenant[/autocard], a [1W] 1/2. After four turns of searching once you played a Lieutenant, you might control [autocard]Lin-Sivvi, Defiant Hero[/autocard]; a [autocard]Ramosian Sky Marshal[/autocard]; and a [autocard]Jhovall Queen[/autocard]. After the same four turns of searching after you played the Persuader, you’d have something like three [autocard]Mothdust Changeling[/autocard]s and a [autocard]Molten Harpy[/autocard]. It’s no wonder Mercenaries never went anywhere. God bless Devon Rule for making them at least somewhat interesting in the Great Designer Search.

The only good thing about Cateran Persuader is that his art is one of the Mercenaries that actually feels like, you know, a [i]mercenary[/i]. Just look at [autocard]Death Charmer[/autocard], [autocard]Misshapen Fiend[/autocard], and [autocard]Skulking Fugitive[/autocard] and ask yourself, “Who would pay money to these idiots?”

19580: Cateran Persuader.author: willpell
19580: Cateran Persuader.text_parsed:
While Mercenaries were not well executed, the idea has potential. Look at Cateran Summons and Cateran Overlord. That's supposed to be the plan, and let's also remember that this was the last set when black got Dark Ritual, and that it had Delraich, which really SHOULD have been a Mercenary. The idea was that while Rebels would slowly promote their "pawns" and build a force over the game, the Evil Empire would lead with their "queen" and back it up with a bunch of disposable mooks.

You know what would have made Mercenaries better? Well first, it might have helped if they weren't called Mercenaries, as that's not exactly a terror-striking name for the Evil Empire's forces; "Oppressors" might have been better (after all, one of the Caterans had that as a name). But more to the point, they should have been able to recruit WITHOUT TAPPING. So they could attack or block while still churning out as many new dorks as you could afford. Ideally combine this with graveyard-reshuffling so that you never run out of goons, and give more and better ways to put a "queen" out early - the net result would eventually be that you'd see Black pursuing a Lord of the Pit-type strategy where you go "all in" with some front-loaded power and then hope that you don't ever default on your contract with the demons by missing a payment.

Now that I think about it, this would make a great archetype for a set of Hive Demon bugs or something. Meanwhile, the actual Mercenaries seem to make more sense in red, which had two of the game's first three Mercenaries in Alliances (the card Mercenaries in Ice Age is harder to justify, but Rogue Skycaptain was PERFECT).

19580: Cateran Persuader.author: Cheza
19580: Cateran Persuader.text_parsed:
@ Aaron:
Mercenaries didn't lose against Rebels because of the mechanic, but because of the stupidity of R&D members to make black creatures weaker than white ones. As if white would have weaker destruction spells or the black reanimation spells were anything close to being overpowered.

And by the way, not rebels have won the Pro-Tour, but Parallax Wave. With this card, you can remove 3 creatures an opponent controls for 3 turns... granting enough time to win with 3 Steadfast Guards.

Rebels have the big problem that although you can play a Ramosian Sergeant, he is a mere 1/1 until you have 3 mana available. It's getting even worse with the Ramosian Lieutenant or Ramosian Captain. By the 5th turn, you'll have one copy of each of them. Quite underwhelming.

The Mercenaries look downwards, but also have low activation cost. Therefore the Cateran Persuader doesn't have to wait for the fourth land until he can use his ability. In the end, you can have more, but maybe weaker creatures. But weakness isn't such a problem, since you still draw cards and cast better cards normally.

With the rebels on the other hand, you won't have mana for casting spells AND using the activated abilities. So this makes you hope for land cards or similar effects (Gaea's Cradle, Mind over Matter or Awakening).

But all this balance was ruined with the print of Lin Sivvi, Defiant Hero. Since she only needs 2 mana to look for an Steadfast Guard, she is REALLY powerful.

If I would have been a designer during Masques block, I would have swapped the rebel and mercenary abilities.
- Marshalling the Troops = search your library for a rebel card.
- Ramosian Foot Soldier = 1/1 First Strike
- Defiant Falcon = 1/2 flying, vigilance
- Ramosian Crossbowman= 1/1 : deal 1 damage to attacking/blocking creature
- Ramosian Seargeant = 2/1 First Strike, search for rebels
- Ramosian Skydiver = 2/1 Flying, protection red/black
- Ramosian Lieutemant = 2/2, search for rebels, other rebels get +1/+1 u.e.o.t.
- Ramosian Captain = 2/3 search for rebels, : target creature gains protection
- Ramosian Commander = 2/4, search for rebels, reshuffle rebels from graveyard into lib.
- Ramosian Sky Marshal = 3/3 flying, search for rebels, when attacked, untap all creatures y.c.

For the mercenaries, it fits better that they are hidden and underwhelming. More powerful creatures are paid (in form of mana). They are Sleeper Agents, Assassins or Devoted Minions in search for their evil master. They are the footman who try to open a portal, so that the hordes of horror can enter this realm. Therefore a black merc should be like the current rebel:

- Phyrexian Sleeper Agent = 1/1 search for mercs

This is underwelming until you have 3 mana. Only then, he can bribe a brute or "call your master". In this theme, it fits quite well to add cards like Dark Ritual or Blood Vassal, since they allow you to activate the ability much earlier. Abilities that have "discard a card" in their activation or upkeep cost also fit, since you'll draw cards and don't have te mana to activate the ability AND casting the new spell. (see Mercenary Knight, Vampire Hounds or Zombie Infestation). And I would have loved to see an Mercenary version of Soldevi Adnate or a black version of Llanowar Elves, just to be able to ramp up even faster.

All in all, I believe it would have been better for black to ramp up until they finally have the power to call the Archdemon to this world then for rebels to finally reach a Jhovall Queen (by the time you have 7 mana).

19580: Cateran Persuader.author: Mode
19580: Cateran Persuader.text_parsed:
He's not that great... at least for now. But there are some uses most people tend to not think of:
- His ability can be used to shuffle your library like Myr Mindservant. Minor function, but it can have some use.
- Artificial Evolution can be used to change "Mercenary" into any other type you like.
This can turn Cateran Persuader into a useful, cheap one-drop fetcher.
Human and Goblin are two good choices for example.
Sneak in a Magus of the Vineyard during your opponent's turn and use the mana.
Sylvan Safekeeper and Weathered Wayfarer make a nice team as well. It unfortunately relies heavily on Artificial Evolution, so it's too risky in general.
You could also use Conspiracy, but there are plenty of other more effective combos for that. But Cateran Persuader might still make a good one-of in a Conspiracy-centered deck.

He has a good deal going for him. Paying three for a 2/2 in black is not uncommon, especialy in earlier sets such as Mercadian Masks. But what makes him so great is his ability when he is blocked. Most players would rather take 2 damage than risk card disadvantage, so often he will get through.

Though there are some nasty things you can do if they do block him. Consider killing the blocking creature with a doom blade or a card like it. This allows you to not loose your creature, kill theirs and make them discard a card all in the same move. Very powerfull combo.

19592: Dark Ritual.author: DrJack
19592: Dark Ritual.text_parsed: In regards to the comments about Dark Ritual being the highest rated card in Mercadian Masques: This may be the most popular card in this set, but the most *powerful* card in that set was probably Rishadan Port. 19593: Soul Channeling.author: OpenSeasonNoobs
19593: Soul Channeling.text_parsed: Lame? How does giving your Phyrexian Dreadnought regenerate seem lame? 2 life is inconsequential in the long run, if you're playing black, be ready to hurt yourself. Today's standard has made people lazy, vampires got all the good parts of black with none of the setbacks and they even synergized them for you. True black isn't hexmage yawgmoth DD with roflthopters, true black hurts you in order to get your amazing things out, they don't just magically appear. That's blue, and blue trades high mana costs for good things, if that is the kind of player you are, don't comment on a black card. If you prefer Regeneration then don't play black. Don't say a perfectly good card is lame just because you're too lazy to find a good card to put it on. 3.5/5 for black regenerating enchantment.

19593: Soul Channeling.author: Ideatog
19593: Soul Channeling.text_parsed:
indeed, 2 life isn't that bad. What makes this card bad is the casting cost. when green can regenerate as an enchantment or an instant for 2 mana (Regeneration and Regenerate, respectively) and no drawback and white can do it at instant speed for 1 (Death Ward), this is just not worth it. And don't forget the relative ease of bypassing regeneration with -1/-1 counters and sacrifice effects.

@noobs True black hurts itself to gain an edge, like Hatred and Doomsday. This card hurts you for minimal returns. I see where you're coming from, but this does not deserve even 2/5.

19595: Snuff Out.text_parsed:
Why is every card art associated with the weatherlight so screwed up?
Compare this with the other art. Liliana snuffing out a candle with a ghost smoking up from it. Clearly she used evil magic to kill someone. Without reading the card, I already think it's a creature removal spell... Probably a subtle one... which it is.
This one: Squee, an immortal goblin who has nothing to do with black magic, overlooking a battle with hovering ships and what look like missiles flying all over the place. What exactly is being "snuffed" out here? And why is a goblin who can't use magic, especially not black magic, the primary subject?
Just looking at this art, my first guess would be that it was a creature card for Squee. After that? A big red damaging spell because of all of the explosions and warm bright colors in the background. Maybe I'd think some kind of blue or white "battle tactics" themed card because of the battle... But a black spell? never.

19602: Flailing Soldier.author: RaymondKHessel
19602: Flailing Soldier.text_parsed:
This guy is a tempo machine! Give him a try if you haven't already. Throw him onto the battlefield first turn and watch the gears turn in your opponent's head as he/she tries to do the quick math on how to best minimize/eliminate this weird threat while still playing their early game ramp. Their eyes will flick from their hand to Flailing Soldier and back and forth--it's like a tennis match. They can kill him or they can play their early game, but they can't do both!

And in multiplayer, he's hilarious. Play politics with a couple of opponents and convince some to save him from dying so they can "hire" him out to attack other players. A perfect Magic card: fun and effective.
19602: Flailing Soldier.text_posted:
This guy is a tempo machine!  Give him a try if you haven't already.  Throw him onto the battlefield first turn and watch the gears turn in your opponent's head as he/she tries to do the quick math on how to best minimize/eliminate this weird threat while still playing their early game ramp.  Their eyes will flick from their hand to Flailing Soldier and back and forth--it's like a tennis match.  They can kill him or they can play their early game, but they can't do both!  

And in multiplayer, he's hilarious.  Play politics with a couple of opponents and convince some to save him from dying so they can "hire" him out to attack other players.  A perfect Magic card: fun and effective.

19616: Crash.author: yyukichigai
19616: Crash.text_parsed:
This is such a weird card. Weird flavor, weird art, weird alternate cost for what it does. I'll admit I can see one or two situations where the alternate cost might come in handy, but those situations are really specific.

Overall this is just a peculiar card. With the extra {1} attached to the hardcast cost this it's not one of the many "strictly better than Shatter" cards, but I still feel like this could be useful in some very strange, very specific deck. For general use... not so much. Better off using Shattering Pulse or something in most cases.
19616: Crash.text_posted:

The flavor text is to differentiate itself from Goblin War Drum, and they work well together. Imagine your opponent having to pay {4} (The usual amount I sac to it) and having to use two or more creatures just to block your 1/1 Goblin Token. I think we could call that a win.

19622: Rushwood Herbalist.author: FirstPrime
19622: Rushwood Herbalist.text_parsed: When I look at a card I ask myself how this is going to help me put an end to my opponent. This is not an offensive threat. It doesn't give me card advantage, in fact it does the opposite. Defensively it's not that hot either, the cost to regenerate is too high. Pay a mana, tap, AND discard? I'd rather just play creatures that can regen themselves, or find another way to regenerate my creatures that is more efficient and much easier to abuse with some sort of combo. Tapping and discarding I find to be expensive costs to pay (unless of course your deck is built around discarding) and to only gain the benefit of regenerating 1 creature, well.... Ya, it's a junk common. Compare this to something like Yavimaya Hollow or Regeneration, both of those are much, much better than this.

19632: Howling Wolf.author: Equinox523
19632: Howling Wolf.text_parsed:
This one takes a little creativity, but like Nesting Wurm, Skyshroud Sentinel or Squadron Hawk, you can use the free cards in your hand to do some neat things. Mercadian Masques introduced the first spellshapers, so I imagine cards like this were meant to help you find things to discard that you wouldn't miss.

Some weird things you can do with this:

Jaya Ballard, Task Mage and other spellshapers: Discard the extra copies and turn them into damage.
Stormbind or Stormscale Anarch: Use your other 3 copies as damage.
Æther Rift: Increase the chances you will have creatures in hand to discard. This can fill up your hand with just creatures and net you some free wolves, freeing up mana for you to do other stuff.
Survival of the Fittest: Allows you to get your best creatures by guaranteeing you have 3 copies in your hand to trade in.
Tortured Existence: Guaranteed ammo to trade for a dead creature.
Strongarm Tactics: You are guaranteed to have a creature to discard, so you can potentially ping your opponent for 4 life in addition to forcing discard.
Skyshroud Vampire: Pop your 3 copies to give this +6/+6 until end of turn. Also works with Vampire Hounds, though slightly cannibalistic.
Sphinx of the Chimes: Guarantees you draw 4 at least one time.
Pox or Smallpox: Provides you with fodder for both sacrifice and discard. May draw ridicule from your opponent.

19633: Land Grant.author: zk3
19633: Land Grant.text_parsed:
Also great for shuffling your deck for free while being card-neutral and still keeping tempo.
You can brainstorm to draw three cards, put your lands onto the top of your library, then shuffle them away. It's great for decks with a few tropical islands.

Sure, you can shuffle with fetchlands, but you can cheat your land count down even further with this card as a combo with brainstorm. Just a thought.

The only downside if revealing your hand, which might be counter-productive in control decks. However, if you're playing blue control then chances are you control through permission, which the card advantage should be overwhelming anyways.

19633: Land Grant.author: Ancient_Mossdog
19633: Land Grant.text_parsed:
This card works some wonders in Legacy and Vintage due to the can find one of your 1-4 land in your deck in order to start your Doom Combo, and to a lesser degree to search for those duel land aforementioned on here.
However, when people say that its better to play them than forests, or that it thins your deck, I would have to disagree. How does it thin your deck? Its just as much a dead draw as a land. If you draw one, its just like drawing a land but you have to reveal your hand. Thats not better than a land. Unless you are running storm or a very wide mana color range, Id rather draw the land, and my land cant be countered.
Generally just use more multi-color lands and less search for them.

19633: Land Grant.author: blurrymadness
19633: Land Grant.text_parsed:
0-Life fetchland that reveals your hand instead.
->If you're in green you're probably somewhat predictable anyway
->if they're discard they get to see your hand anyway
->if they're control they can't really let your threats get by and beat on them just to counter something better. Have lopsided and/or efficient creatures and you're good.
->If you run duals, you're searching for anything you want basically

This all adds up to a card that's quite efficient and not $20 a piece; which is handy.

19634: Ancestral Mask.author: BegleOne
19634: Ancestral Mask.text_parsed:
Back when I was very raw, with just a few booster packs to my name, I started enrolling in Type II tournaments not having a clue what I was doing. On a good night my opponents would get mana screwed and I'd win a game or two.

The first deck I had any success with consisted of playing as many enchantments as possible and putting this on a decent critter. I probaably played ten standard tournaments while Masques was legal, each with a variation of "critter + Ancestral Mask + every other enchantment I have".

It was surprisingly good, mainly because of the power of this card. Multicolor was a pain in Masques, but was made easy with Invasion; at that point I'd accelerate with Wild Growths and Fertile Grounds, plop out a few more utility enchantments and then play Ancestral Mask and Diplomatic Immunity on some little flier or something. I never came close to winning, but by Odyssey I'd always be in the middle of the rankings by playing this card in what was never more than a $30 deck.

19634: Ancestral Mask.text_parsed: I was trying to explain to one of my friends who just started Magic that enchant creatures, unless they can return to your hand (Rancor for instance) end up becoming very punishing to removal as they simultaneously make a creature a threat, and put all your eggs in one basket. He was looking through my collection and found a playset of these, and asked well, what about them? He also pulled out a bunch of Blanchwood Armors and Ethereal Armors. I had to revise my uppity stance on Enchant Creatures then and there. Also, gnarly artwork.

19639: Ferocity.author: Equinox523
19639: Ferocity.text_parsed:
What an interesting card. It mitigates the typical card disadvantage associated with auras by potentially leaving behind +1/+1 counters, while not doing anything immediate and thus not demanding immediate removal itself. It was printed in the wake of Rancor, one of the most obscenely powerful creature enchantments of all time, and understandably with lots of jobs on the line, Mercadian Masques was not a particularly powerful set.

This is potentially useful with things that benefit from +1/+1 counters, such as graft creatures, or spikes, and has interesting synergy with the slith creatures. It forces you to choose if you want to block Arcbound Slith and have it grow, or to let it through and let it grow. If you kill it, then you can set off its modular ability and move those counters over to another creature.
19639: Ferocity.text_posted:

It mitigates the typical card disadvantage associated with auras by potentially leaving behind +1/+1 counters, while not doing anything immediate and thus not demanding immediate removal itself. This is potentially useful with things that benefit from +1/+1 counters, such as graft creatures, or spikes, and has interesting synergy with the slith creatures.  It forces you to choose if you want to block [autocard]Arcbound Slith[/autocard] and have it grow, or to let it through and let it grow.  If you kill it, then you can set off its modular ability and move those counters over to another creature.

19640: Invigorate.author: Kirbster
19640: Invigorate.text_parsed:
This card's alternate cost is great. Despite being tapped out, your creature can flatten a once-threatening blocker. The life gain is negligable, especially considering your still-living creature will be likely to make up the difference in short order.

Worst case scenario, it can also give that one extra point of damage to an unblocked attacker for free.

19640: Invigorate.author: Aaron_Forsythe
19640: Invigorate.text_parsed:
Aaron’s Random Card Comment of the Day #43, 12/1/10

“Now I am finally strong enough to lift a wumpus!”
--Mercadian dryad

Of the six Dryads in Mercadian Masques, the highest power is 2. Even with +4/+4, they’d only be 6/6 themselves, the same size as a Hunted Wumpus. Can you lift something over your head that’s the same size as you?

Anyway…

Many of the “free spells” in Mercadian Masques are well made. Gush is write-a-book-about-it powerful in Vintage, but that’s cool. Unmask has seen tons of play across many formats. And this card, Invigorate, does a bunch of neat stuff:

* It acts as a free combat trick or counter to toughness-based removal.
* It combines cleverly with anti-life gain cards like False Cure, Kavu Predator, and Sulfuric Vortex.
* It can be used politically in multiplayer games.
* It works really amazingly with infect.

All that upside is a reasonable trade for the one extra mana you have to pay for the card normally. Of course, the alternate cost (a) doesn’t work well as a finisher and (b) reads poorly to less experienced players who overvalue life and undervalue mana efficiency. For that reason alone I doubt we’d print this card at common today.

19640: Invigorate.author: WotC_KennethNagle
19640: Invigorate.text_parsed:
I ran this in my "Fastest Stompy Deck Ever" that I would use to turn 3 kill people in Multiplayer that were mean to me last game. Invigorate did lots of that heavy-lifting. However, I discovered that Skyshroud Cutter is the worst 0-drop ever in multiplayer. Invigorate and Skyshroud Cutter have different mechanics! Invigorate gives ONE opponent life, Skyshroud Cutter gives EACH OTHER PLAYER life.

I played that deck for over a year before noticing that. It made me so angry. The slight change in the mechanic punished me, the player that had already compartmentalized "giving an opponent life as an alternate cost." I make sure that we don't have a "Skyshroud Cutter incident" in Magic sets I work on.

19640: Invigorate.author: RaymondKHessel
19640: Invigorate.text_parsed:
Masques Block green made everybody a little paranoid in combat, and this little (COMMON!) beauty is the main reason why. One of the few comforting things about facing down an opponent's Blastoderm was the knowledge that it couldn't be Invigorated. (That, and, of course, that it wouldn't stay on the battlefield to beat your face in for too many more turns.)

But Invigorate was a monstrous card then and too destabilizing to be allowed in Pauper today.

19646: Hickory Woodlot.author: achilleselbow
19646: Hickory Woodlot.text_parsed:
Question: Can I tap this the second time (plus a forest) to cast Harrow, and sacrifice this land for Harrow's cost before its own sacrifice triggers? It seems I should be able to:

1. Tap, remove last counter. Since mana sources are immediate, I should have two green mana before anything else can happen.
2. State-based ability goes on the stack. Since this ability is not itself a mana source, I can respond to it with instants.
3. I cast Harrow, sacrificing the Hickory Woodlot which is still in play until its own ability resolves.

Am I doing this right?

Edit: Yea, that's what it seems like. Oh well, there goes my mediocre combo idea. At least I can still use it once early game and then cast a Harrow later on.

19646: Hickory Woodlot.author: Nathreet
19646: Hickory Woodlot.text_parsed:
IMO the double mana depletion lands are highly underrated. There's a reason why they see tournament play; they're a must for any fast deck or a deck that saves up and goes boom all at once. They also make it easier to run fewer lands while still affording your spells.

One of my better decks is a 16 land glimpse of nature deck with these. With less land I can continue the chain-drawing glimpse longer when I finally go boom and yet I can still afford the few expensive spells.

One of my better decks is a 16 land [autocard]glimpse of nature[/autocard] deck with these.  With less land I can continue the chain-drawing glimpse longer when I finally go boom and yet I can still afford the few expensive spells.

19655: Security Detail.author: Wulfsten

Mind-bogglingly poor design. I can't imagine why R&D thought this ability needed to be mana-activated, and why the card itself needed to cost so much. As other people have said, this enchantment should have cost one or two mana at most, and the ability should take place automatically during your upkeep (or, for "security detail" flavour, during your end step).

A waste of a perfectly lovely concept.

19655: Security Detail.author: longwinded
19655: Security Detail.text_parsed:
As of this posting, this is officially the worst-rated card on Gatherer (with 0.717 / 5 stars).

I can see why it's rare, because then relatively few people are cursed with owning one, as it's a "I dare you to find a use for me" puzzle card, and only the people who want the mental thrill of breaking it will choose to seek it out on the secondary market. I can see why it's at 4 CMC, because at lower cost it could actually be used in the early game, leaving the card bad , but not puzzle bad.

I just can't see why this is mana-activated AND limited to one use per turn. One or the other, sure. Mana-activated to prevent an arbitrarily large number of activations from going on the stack in a turn. Once per turn to limit it to one token per turn (say, so you can't get a token, chump block, and get another). Why? So you can't follow-up Wrath with a chump in the same turn before turn 6? Because with both of those being CMC 4, ANY mana cost for the activation limits it to turn 5 or later (barring acceleration).

I think the puzzle got a little too constrained.

19659: Wave of Reckoning.author: Dragon_Bloodthirsty
19659: Wave of Reckoning.text_parsed: As a "Build Around Me" Wrath variant, the Wave excels most in formats where you are able to pack your deck with creatures that have higher toughness than power, especially if those creatures have Lifelink.  In a multiplayer format, where destroying lots of opposing creatures without wiping out your own, the Wave is a viable budget option with some strategic merit over the Wrath.  Being five mana keeps the Wave from being competitive in duels.

This card says "Screw the rules, I make them!" And it does so very well. Obviously creatures with toughness greater than power are a must for this deck. Good combos include Repercussion and Doran, the Siege Tower. Lifelink is another theme you can work with. If your meta favors deathtouch and infect, this card is 100% awesomeness, killing anything with deathtouch and reducing anything with infect or wither's power to 0.

It is a bit pricey, but you expect a sweeper and bomb to be so pricy.

Just look at the card.
A single extra card requires you to pay {{8WWWWW}} and give your opponent 6 life.
That's seriously not worth the card advantage, is it?

19663: Cornered Market.author: psyklone
19663: Cornered Market.text_parsed:
If you want the destroy ability, the Eye works better. But this works better as far as the other mechanic goes.

With Eye your opponents can still trigger "When you play a spell" abilities. With this you can't.
This locks the board down, Eye does too, but its destroy affect may be limited (or hurt you more), and it still may not defeat your opponents abilities.

Personally I'd totally play free (via affinity) artifacts, in order to draw cards (vedalken archmage) even if they never actually make it into play.

Something to think about.

19664: Crackdown.author: Ferlord
19664: Crackdown.text_parsed:
Downloading new intel, Agent. You can thank the Weatherlight for this intel...

Ta-Spon: Cold, Merciless... Paranoid. He's one of Cho-Manno's most dangerous gang lieutenants.

He is directly responsible for Cho-Manno's police division. He takes justice into his own hands, killing criminals without a trial. He defines the term "Judge, Jury, Executioner".

Him and his Cho-Arrim rebels would normally be patrolling Mercadia's streets, hassling stores and merchants for "protection money". However, he hid in the Rushwood Forst because of a rumour of an assassination attempt on his life. He is right to hide.

Killing him would greatly weaken Cho-Manno's grip on the Mercadian markets and, as a result, cripple Cho-Manno's "protection fund".

19665: Common Cause.author: Lateralis0ne
19665: Common Cause.text_parsed:
Except, mrredhatter, it says "as long as the ALL share a color". Doesn't that imply that, in order to get the +2/+2 boost, ALL creatures IN PLAY must share a color? Plus, if they meant that all creatures get +2/+2 for each color they share, then it should be worded as such. As it is written now, Common Cause is really sub-par, unless in a mono-color deck. I might be wrong on all this, but it seems to me that you're mis-interpreting the rules text of the card.

EDIT And now that the Oracle is back, if ONE creature on ANY SIDE of the board is a different color from the rest...the effect is lost. Thus, it really is a sub-par card. Celestial Dawn, Painter's Servant, and any card that changes creature color on a global scale will work with this card, but even then, your opponents get the bonus as well.

Kind of a lame card, in my opinion.

19665: Common Cause.author: DarthParallax
19665: Common Cause.text_parsed:
the sad thing about this card is, the stupid word 'all' and how it used to be applied.
first, you can see that the first word on the card as it SHOULD be read is really a hidden 'all'- so it's 'all non-artifact creatures blah blah blah'

second, that immediately shows that whatever you are supposed to do with this card, you need to make sure you load up on one-sided Wrath effects, since I have never seen a deck that that ran only artifact creatures in the creature section-- even Affinity had the Disciple of the Vault, and looking back to ancient Magic days, if they WERE running a creatureless deck or a deck whose creatures were only artifacts, you'd be looking at super-uber shit like Mishra's Workshop and the like. Could you hope they are running Darksteel/Blightsteel + Tinker Combo?....why would you WANT them to?
the stuff against which this works is 10x better than this itself, even if Mr. Red Hatter is right about Fusion Elementals, because trying to power those guys out off of Moxen and Lotuses seems...uh...a massive waste of Power?

the only way I can see this being useful at all is in multiplayer, purely because those games are better for trying to set up convoluted niche situations, which this card is literally the Lord of.

19665: Common Cause.author: Mode
19665: Common Cause.text_parsed:
This card is too unstable and effectively useless without a combo.

I wouldn't even start to try solving that problem with removal.
Once you reach the point where you can reliably control what's on your opponent's side of the field,
there won't be any creatures left on yours to profit from this enchantment.

Instead, try to make sure the condition is true no matter what by altering all creatures' colors.
Darkest Hour or Painter's Servant would work.
19665: Common Cause.text_posted:

[autocard]Darkest Hour[/autocard] or [autocard]Painter's Servant[/autocard] would work.

19668: Sand Squid.author: fissionessence
19668: Sand Squid.text_parsed:
Andrew's Occasional Random Card of the Day #6 - 7/2/2011 - Sand Squid

Sometimes a top-down design goes a couple different directions, resulting in a flavorful card with awkward game play. Often, this awkward game play is known as 'tension', but I think there's a fine line between the two . . . and I think Sand Squid is a little further into the realm of awkward. Four mana for a 2/2 unblockable isn't particularly exciting, especially since it's not guaranteed to even be unblockable. Islandwalk, arggh. Alternatively, you can use it to lock down an opposing creature. Four mana for removal in the form of a vulnerable creature isn't especially good, although it is blue, so it's close. Still, though, the two options you have with this card make it 'versatile', but awkward. Essentially, pick what you want the slot in your deck to do, and find a better card. But it definitely feels like a sand squid! (Especially with its Oracle creature type update!)

On a side note, Mercadian Masques is an interesting set for me. When I started playing Magic, Nemesis was the newest expansion, so Masques just missed out on holding a lot of nostalgia for me. Still, there is a little sentimentality in it for me, so even though I hadn't been really familiar with Sand Squid before I clicked the 'Random Card' link a few minutes ago, its expansion symbol and top-down design still resonate with me more than my initial Spikey arguments might suggest.

19669: Saprazzan Bailiff.author: N03y3D33R
19669: Saprazzan Bailiff.text_parsed:
Interesting but often very situational utility card. Mess up enemy Artifact and Enchantment decks or Get him out before you mill your artifact/enchantment decks and then sacrifice him to essentially grab all the artifacts and enchantments you need.

I once ran him alongside Fool's Demise and a self-mill artifact deck with 4 of each Artifact Land and a few copies of Thirst for Knowledge, it was a pretty interesting way to get a handful of useful cards quickly without having to worry about discard effects. This being said, it was in no way a 'competitive' deck.

19676: Statecraft.author: KrosanGardener
19676: Statecraft.text_parsed:
Most control strategies using creatures defensively are unreliable (because of kill spells and evasion), want their creatures to deal damage (Plumeveil), or have very little fear that their creatures will take too much damage (Wall of Denial).

The main use of this card seems to be to give your prodigal sorcerer (or other similar utility creatures) the ability to block. Two questions there: why are you using prodigal sorcerer in constructed? And why not just play removal, plumeveil, or something like propaganda?
19676: Statecraft.text_posted:
Most control strategies using creatures defensively are unreliable (because of kill spells and evasion), want their creatures to deal damage ([autocard]Plumeveil[/autocard]), or have very little fear that their creatures will take too much damage ([autocard]Wall of Denial[/autocard]).  

The main use of this card seems to be to give your prodigal sorcerer (or other similar utility creatures) the ability to block.  Two questions there: why are you using prodigal sorcerer in constructed?  And why not just play removal, plumeveil, or something like [autocard]propaganda[/autocard]?

19676: Statecraft.author: N03y3D33R
19676: Statecraft.text_parsed:
It's splashable and makes all your creatures nigh invincible. If you're playing burn this is hilarious to pair with a Kiln Fiend and Fling, since Fling is doing the damage rather than your giant Kiln Fiend.

In addition the flavor and use of this in a Multiplayer game like EDH is fantastic if you don't rely on Combat Damage to win. It makes attacking you seem like a waste of resources and they will often focus on attacking your opponents instead.

19677: Shoving Match.author: Mode
19677: Shoving Match.text_parsed:
The flavor is really hilarious when you visualize it, especially because it's usually out of place.

Consider all the different shapes, races and attitudes there are among creatures,
which makes shoving each other in a grumpy humanoid manner often ridiculously unfitting.
Just imagine a Leery Fogbeast, a Reaper from the Abyss, an Alloy Myr or even Barrin, Master Wizard being involved.

That aside, even if a Waterfront Bouncer fittingly shoves someone else, this card still invokes and awkward scenery:
Everyone that's been shoved just keeps lying there on the floor, motionless like a bag of sand, not because of anything serious but simply out of sheer lazyness to get back up, with a lethargic facial expression until next upkeep.

*Frontline Medic approaches the battlefield, various bodies lying on the ground*
Medic: By Aurelia! Sir Tajic, are you alright? What happened?
Tajic: Ugh. I've been shoved, man.
Medic: ...beg your pardon, Sir?
Tajic: That wizard over there. *Slightly raises his arm to point to a robed man lying about 2 meters next to him*
That dick just came over and... shoved me away. Shoved him back, haha.
Medic: Sir! There is a war going on, your people need you!
Tajic: Well, what do you you want me to do? STAND UP?

19681: Misdirection.text_parsed:
I play the Show and Sneak deck and being a combo deck, my favorite spells to misdirect are.

1. Hymn to Tourach (You can pitch a card and still come out ahead!! Is this kind of value even legal??)
2. Thought Seize (Thats awesome, you get to see your opponents hand and watch him discard himself)
3. Diabolic Edict (My Emrakul and Progenitus died to this many times but Misdirection gives the opprotunity to refund some value)
4. Orim's Chant (A storm player is trying to go off with this as backup? I say NO!!, try again later)

19681: Misdirection.author: Chamale
19681: Misdirection.text_parsed:
This definitely sees play in Vintage with all the powerful targeted effects. I once watched this happen:

Player 1: Ancestral Recall
Player 2: Ancestral Recall in response
Player 1: Misdirection it to me
Player 2: Misdirection your Misdirection.

At this point the only legal choice for Misdirection was for player 1's Ancestral Recall to target player 2 instead, so he drew 6 cards. As you'd expect, he won that game.

19683: Cowardice.author: N03y3D33R
19683: Cowardice.text_parsed:
Now the only removal is untargeted, bouncing, or counterspells, convenient since you're running blue!

Here's a viable win condition for Masques Blue. If you've been playing your hand right they're behind in tempo because you bounced their lands with Hoodwink and you've been preventing them from dropping any creatures with Rishadan Pirate cards or Ports. You're Coastal Piracy enchantment guarantees every pirate or Cloud Sprite not only is slapping them for 1-2 damage each turn, but also drawing you cards to keep ahead and keep them behind, so they really have little to no chance to take advantage of this spell because you'll just drop the same pirate from before and force them to pay mana or sac something.

It's a very effective enchantment, and if your control deck has no creatures, all the better, because you can use abilities as well as spells to bounce them.

19695: Notorious Assassin.author: Dynamic_Reversist
19695: Notorious Assassin.text_parsed:
Remember, that Masques Block followed the aggressive Tempest and combo-ridden Urza Blocks...this era in Magic was considerably slower in play, and the Spellshapers were printed in that environment probably because their slow nature was less a liablilty and made up for in their versatility. I am so glad to see their even brief return in Time Spiral Block, as their versatility is a boon to casual multiplayer formats, and it imrpoves my selection when building my admittedly too many Spellshaper Tribal decks. They were a great idea executed nicely, and this Dark Banishing machine got beastly in Limited, having pulled a few.

Avatar of Woe, printed two sets later, is of course more powerful, but considering the gap between it and the other Avatars, its unfair to judge it alongside, as balance was not maintained in this case (This is not a complaint against the card, just relative to the environment it was printed in). That said, Notorious Assassin covers his cost over two(or more) turns, meaning he is more reliably placed on the board in early game.
19695: Notorious Assassin.text_posted:

19698: Cateran Overlord.author: Equinox523
19698: Cateran Overlord.text_parsed: Looking at this now, it's not hard to understand why Rebels outclassed Mercenaries, even back in the day. While Rebels searched up, Mercenaries searched down - wherein lay the problem. Without Dark Ritual and its ilk, it's hard to get the bigger Mercenaries into play in the first place, in order to look for their minions. With Rebels, the flow of the game dictates that the longer it goes, the more mana you have available. This made grabbing Jhovall Queen possible, and even without the amazing Lin Sivvi, Defiant Hero, you could raise a pretty staunch army that adapted to the changing board. Grabbing a 2/2 Mercenaries, however, would not necessarily help much on turn 7.
19698: Cateran Overlord.text_posted: Looking at this now, it's not hard to understand why Rebels outclassed Mercenaries, even back in the day.  While Rebels searched up, Mercenaries searched down - wherein lay the problem.  Without [autocard]Dark Ritual[/autocard] and its ilk, it's hard to get the bigger Mercenaries into play in the first place, in order to look for their minions.  With Rebels, the flow of the game dictates that the longer it goes, the more mana you have available.  This made grabbing [autocard]Jhovall Queen[/autocard] possible, and even without the amazing [autocard]Lin Sivvi, Defiant Hero[/autocard], you could raise a pretty staunch army that adapted to the changing board.  Grabbing a 2/2 Mercenaries, however, would not necessarily help much on turn 7.

19698: Cateran Overlord.author: NARFNra
19698: Cateran Overlord.text_parsed:
@Equinox523:
Weirdly enough, I think that the mercenaries could have had a chance if they'd not had to tap to activate their search ability. It wouldn't be too broken because they'd still pay mana to do it, but you could get out some of the weaker ones (Cateran Persuader) and search out the cheapest creatures very quickly. The Rebels would have been able to slowly build up, the mercenaries would have been able to quickly spam weak creatures. The end result would be that Rebels would get big quickly, and Mercenaries would get meatshields quickly. I think that'd be kind of neat.

As it is though, there's no point to playing a large creature then searching up a smaller one.

19704: Haunted Crossroads.author: Artscrafter
19704: Haunted Crossroads.text_parsed:
This is basically the same effect as Volrath's Stronghold.

Advantages of this:
- Cheaper activation cost
- Not legendary, so doesn't die to an opponent playing their own
- Doesn't require using a land slot for something that produces colorless mana
- Can use this more than once per turn without needing a way to untap things

Advantages of Volrath's Stronghold:
- Doesn't cost anything to play, so the first activation is cheaper
- Uncounterable
- Also can produce mana
- Enchantments are generally easier to remove than lands

I would generally go with the Stronghold given the choice, but this is still pretty good.

19714: Blood Hound.author: NARFNra
19714: Blood Hound.text_parsed:
IT SPECIFIES AT THE BEGINNING OF YOUR END STEP!

You know what that means?

Sundial of the Infinite stops it from losing counters, since you skip your end step and it's not an end of turn thing. So hey, very angry hound. If you're having trouble from lack of evasion, you can activate Sundial and play Madcap Skills in the space of the same amount of mana it costs to play Blood Hound. So hey, up to you.

Little weird that it says end of turn on the card though. Must be because of the whole "gets counters on anyone's turn but only loses them on yours" thing.

19714: Blood Hound.author: HawkeaterMoth
19714: Blood Hound.text_parsed: I've played variations on a casual deck with this guy for years. Flame Rift, Ancient Tomb and Fling were the obvious ones around the time when he came out, but when Tarnished Citadel came out during Odyssey that was the final piece. I'd play a deck that only needed to successfully attack with him once, and it was pretty easy to keep the board clear in red, and then I'd play Final Fortune to repeat. The counters build up fast when you're killing yourself with the tombs and the citadels. Lava Hounds is another obvious buddy. The deck I run them in is red and white, you can play life gain cards like Life Burst in case you're getting a bit too close when getting the combo ready, but in general, you only need to get the Hound to attack once to get some necessary cards in motion. One of my favorite Johnny cards.

19716: Squee, Goblin Nabob.author: SunshineTheBlond
19716: Squee, Goblin Nabob.text_parsed:
For those of you that don't know Squee's story:

He was a cabin-boy on the Weatherlight. He cooked, clean, and shot a cannon. How good was he at that? He only took down Volrath's ship single-handedly. He also convinced the entirety of Mercadia to back off the Weatherlight crew, because he's so intelligent. Oh, and he get's captured by Crovax and killed, before coming back to life because he's immortal.

Crovax sent him into the chambers, where Ertai killed him dead so many times he got exhausted and had to recharge at a mana battery, which Squee overloaded and killed Ertai with.

Then he gets scooped up by Gerrard, and later lives through the whole ship getting smashed into the ocean.

Yeah. Stupid goblin my foot.

19719: Robber Fly.author: Gabriel422
19719: Robber Fly.text_parsed:
Everything about this card is wrong.

- Why does it have flying when it requires a creature to block it?
- Why is it a three mana 1/1 so the opponent seriously can just let it through?
- Why are two things each requiring outside support tacked onto one another?

I mean, you need a Lure effect or this is just a bad Suntail Hawk. Then you need something like Megrim or else the ability does almost nothing. After all that and hoping they don't Bolt your Fly, you start to hope they control a creature with flying and have a sizable hand.

Masques did have many awkward cards, but this really tops them all.

19721: Puppet's Verdict.author: Kirbster
19721: Puppet's Verdict.text_parsed:
Alright, you have a whole mess of small creatures and your opponent is looming over you with an army of 3+ power fatties. Now in your best interests... you want to lose the coin flip on Puppet's Verdict. Your goal is to fail it. After the coin is flipped, it comes out under what your opponent called... so you "lost" the flip.

Or did you?

19721: Puppet's Verdict.author: OmegaSerris
19721: Puppet's Verdict.text_parsed: I agree with Kirbster. Chances are, the "lost" effect is the one you want. Gobbos (or Kobolds, if you're going old school) is the only type of deck which would pump out large amount of creatures. Most high power die at the end of turn anyways, or have some equally negative downside. If you think of dragons, usually, you only have one or two because the others eat their kill spells. And if you're playing a field wipe, you're already down on your luck. But anyways, it's all semantics. It will work the same either way it's worded.

19725: Cave-In.author: Internet_decks_lame
19725: Cave-In.text_parsed:
The element of surprise will always shift the balance of the battlefield in most cases. Any combo player I am sure has had their attempts foiled by even the silliest cards that usually never see much play. This can easily be one of those cards that has that kind of impact. Even though token generation and/or mass creature decks have become rather scarce in the newer age of mtg decks, I still believe any card that offers a replacement for its casting cost should never be taken lightly.
Not to mention you don't even need to run this card main deck, as long as your deck has Burning Wish. Now lets say... just for an example, your opponent spawns a blillion tokens of whateter by turn 2. Even if they have the first turn. Now your turn 2, you cast burning wish, grab Cave-in, pitch whatever, and.... C-C-C-COMBO BREAKER! Remeber that one... Killer Instinct... good ol days baby. If you are lucky enough, and have stumbled upon this reading... Check out this card next: Pulverize. Now that is another serious weapon that can easily respond to Trinisphere (A card that should without a doubt be ban instantly, once upon a time was... but now un-ban...?) stupidity on turn 2 using a burning wish.

Blue has dominated the game of magic for who knows how many years now. Its for this very reason, the color offers a lot of similar replacement effects for casting a spell. Daze, and Force of Will are the perfect examples. And because most players in Legacy and good old type 1, usually run turn 1 kill, or some kind of lock combo, those are the only spells that offer and kind of resistance against the such. The newer leylines are some what of a nice edition, although if they are not in your opening hand... they become a 4 cmc drop which might not even have a chance at seeing the battlefield with the accelerated pace of Storm and or Lock. I am sure any new card that is given a replacement effect for casting, needs thorough examination, and for that same reason not many of these cards exist.

[autocard]Daze[/autocard], and [autocard]Force of Will[/autocard] are the perfect examples.  And because most players in Legacy and good old type 1, usually run turn 1 kill, or some kind of lock combo, those are the only spells that offer and kind of resistance against the such.  The newer leylines are some what of a nice edition, although if they are not in your opening hand... they become a 4 cmc drop which might not even have a chance at seeing the battlefield with the accelerated pace of Storm and or Lock.  I am sure any new card that is given a replacement effect for casting, needs thorough examination, and for that same reason not many of these cards exist.

19728: Silverglade Pathfinder.author: Salient
19728: Silverglade Pathfinder.text_parsed:
Your deck can only have four cards named Rampant Growth.

Ian Malcolm, Silverglade Pathfinder: "the kind of control you're attempting simply is... it's not possible. If there is one thing the history of evolution has taught us it's that growth will not be contained. Growth breaks free, it expands to new territories and crashes through barriers, painfully, maybe even dangerously, but, uh... well, there it is."

Henry Wu, Rules Lawyer: "You're implying that a deck composed entirely of creatures and lands will... ramp?"

Ian: "No, I'm, I'm simply saying that Rampant Growth... finds a way."

19731: Lithophage.author: RedAtrocitus
19731: Lithophage.text_parsed:
Such a beating for whoever plays it. It some situations, it can just win, obviously, a 7/7 coming out pretty early (though not even insanely early). But with no evasion, or trample, or protection, it just is juicy value for your opponent who can use chump blockers as Strip Mine until they decide to burn a removal spell or you finally just let it die.

And for ramping it out with rituals, you need to feed this thing mountains to maintain it, red may not need a huge mana base to do things, but it is certainly going nowhere if it can't cast more than one mana spells once a turn until it finally runs out of Mountains and has nothing going for it. Granted, ramping to this thing, then bolting chumpers until this thing wins could work if your opponent is limiting himself to one 1 mana play a turn as well.

19734: Erithizon.author: scumbling1
19734: Erithizon.text_parsed: I have to wonder what the mentality was during the making of Mercadian Masques block. This, Pangosaur, and Megatherium were all printed, as rares, in the same set. They are terrible by any standard (even back then, they were bad) and fill the same design space. I don't accept that they were following Urza's block as an excuse for low power level; there is plenty of room between broken and MM block! Besides, that wouldn't account for such overlap in aggressively-costed green rare creatures with downsides.

He's a 4-turn clock if you play a heavy-handed control deck or are simply crafty. A RG deck with Volcanic Fallout can clear the board during the end step, then run this guy out there for a good bit of damage (and probably with haste!)

He's hardly "awesome", but fun casual decks can be had with him and again; if you're playing a brutal RG or BG control variant, he grows without any assistance; allowing you to Infest, Toxic Deluge, anger of the gods, etc; everyone else, while you get a growing creature.

With the number of boardwipes in EDH; I would've thought this would be a more popular card.

19734: Erithizon.author: Kirbster
19734: Erithizon.text_parsed:
Comboing him with Cytoplast Manipulator is the new favourite trick, but this guy has more uses than you'd expect. If your opponent has no creatures, since Erithizon's ability is not optional, they have to put the counter on one of your guys. Since the ability targets, though, your opponent will also not be able to put the counter on any of their guys with Shroud. Heck, since you own Erithizon, they can't even choose their own creatures with Hexproof! Not a bad jab at those hexproof decks.

Erithizon also combos with Hunter of Eyeblights and/or Kulrath Knight, and since black is good at keeping your opponent's board clear, there's a good chance you'll get a fair number of free counters on your own guys.

19737: Food Chain.author: lukemol
19737: Food Chain.text_parsed:
Since this is green and green has a decent number of big creatures this is potentially fantastic as mana acceleration. But it's gotta be played right. And it's probably absolutely useless in some formats (Legacy....), but for games that will likely be going longer, like casual or multiplayer casual games, it can be great. Think about it, your first 2 turns you play 2 creatures with a CMC of 1. If the first one was Llanowar Elves. On turn 3 play this. With Llanowar Elves, BOOM! Exile both creatures and you've got a Turn 4 Terra Stomper or better. Or if you tap Llanowar elves for first, you can get a Terastodon, Symbiotic Wurm, or any other 8 mana creature out. Or, alternately you could play another creature (preferably with CMC 4) and exile all of them for a potential 9 mana on turn 4. Myojin of Life's Web that early would be nice. Or a number of other things. It just has to be played by someone who knows how to properly utilize it.

It does seem pretty useless at first sight though.

19737: Food Chain.author: Caiolaurenti
19737: Food Chain.text_parsed:
Actually, the reference this card makes to the food chain is incorrect. In ecology, we say that the amount of energy transferred from a lower level consumer to a higher level consumer - we call that liquid energy - is always considerably smaller than the amount of energy the lower level consumer received. This happens because part of that energy is spent to maintain the metabolism of the lower level consumer, and therefore is not absorbed upon advancing in the food chain. Thus, regarding the flavor of the card, it makes no sense that the creature should provide the player, considering the player is at the higher level (wich I think is the only conceivable option, considering the card's effect), more mana than it needed to be cast - this mana being, in this metaphor, what we defined as liquid energy.
As for the card itself
4.5/5
19737: Food Chain.text_posted:

This happens because part of that energy is spent to maintain the metabolism of the lower level consumer, and therefore is not absorbed upon advancing in the food chain. Thus, regarding the flavor of the card, it makes no sense that the creature should provide the player, considering the player is at the higher level (wich I think is the only conceivable option, considering the card's effect), more mana than it needed to be cast - this mana being, in this metaphor, what we defined as [i]liquid energy[/i].

19737: Food Chain.author: Bbone37
19737: Food Chain.text_parsed:
At first I thought Prossh and this wouldnt make an infinite combo, but I didnt take into consideration the Kobold tokens he creates.
1) So you play Prossh, make 6 dudes, sac Prossh for 7 green, a Kobold for R, and 1 for B. You have 9 mana and 4 tokens.
2) Recast Prossh for 8, leaving 1 G, make 8 tokens, 12 Kobolds on the field.
3) Keep repeating, saccing more tokens each time, but always making more tokens next cast then you previously had to sac.

So yeah, eventually you would be making a very large amount of 0/1 Kobolds. I guess haste and overrun at that point?

19739: Collective Unconscious.author: majinara
19739: Collective Unconscious.text_parsed:
It's alright in token decks or decks that animate their lands in some way. In other decks though...
When does it draw you a lot of cards? When you have a huge army. But if you have a huge army, why didn't you win yet?
And, think about it, when does a green creature based deck needs cards most? After a board wipe, or when it's creatures died in some other way, so the pilot of the deck can play more creatures. But that is also exactly the point when this card does nothing.

So... good for tokens and land animators, bad in other decks.

I disagree a bit with Kirbster. Harmonize costs 4 instead of 6, and it always draws you cards. That is a huge plus. Also, harmonize gives you a nice boost just when you played your lands and might otherwise run out of steam. It's a great midgame card. This one is more of a late game card.

19739: Collective Unconscious.author: Bbone37
19739: Collective Unconscious.text_parsed:
"Almost always draws more cards than Harmonize."

I fixed this for you. Majinara is correct, imho. While creatures and mana is not at a loss in green decks, the fact that both usually rely on have dudes out makes this card only situationally better than harmonize.

Harmonize costs less, so we can assume you can either play it earlier, or have mana left to play the cards you just drew. At more on this card, that same may thing may not be true.

Also, as Majinara pointed out, after a wipe would be a great time to draw cards, and with harmonize you can. After a wipe, under most circumstances, this card would not draw anything.

This is still a good card, however, and def deserves a place in green EDH decks. Even if not a token-based deck. Drawing cards in edh is a good thing, and as long as you can draw, let's say, 4+ cards (sure can draw 4 cards for 5CMC, but that is and this is . 6cmc to draw 4 in seems fair to me), this would be worth casting IMO.

3.5/5 IMO. useful in token based decks, and EDH decks w/o access to more efficient (read ) draw spells

19740: Foster.author: Gabriel422
19740: Foster.text_parsed:
Wow, this thing is utterly broken. So easy to make it "draw your deck and play everything for free" (Say with Ashnod's Altar). Well you have to sacrifice them all, but something as simple as 1x Bogarden Hellkite + 1x Emrakul (to reuse the dragon) in your deck wins you the game outright. Even without something like the Altar, a Nantuko Husk can easily grow to 20/20 in a single turn - just fill your deck with token generators (or better yet, Eldrazi token generators, as they pay all the mana costs for you).

I'm surprised I didn't even know this card. I don't think this was considered broken back then, when things like Tolarian Academy and Parallax Tide were Standard-legal.

It's a sorcery-speed Mask of the Mimic that doesn't require you to sacrifice a creature, and consequently costs more! It's also a single-target Doubling Chant, and possibly the inspiration for that card (as Polymorph was to Mass Polymorph).

Pretty cool!

Bifurcate is Timmy's version of Johnny's Mask of the Mimic, although they can both be used by the other. I like them both, but I'm a Johnny, and only one of them can be used to make a second-turn Phyrexian Dreadnought...


P.S. Apparently a generic creature is worth and a speed upgrade. Who knew?

I think you're able to look through your deck for a land, as long as it has been Man-Landed (like Mishra's Factory or thanks to Kamahl, Fist of Krosa).

Since the rules say, "Search your library for a permanent card with the same name as target nontoken creature..." and the man-land retains its name AND isn't a token in addition, it's legal.

19742: Game Preserve.author: GrimjawxRULES
19742: Game Preserve.text_parsed:
Perhaps Hunted Wumpus was depicted because this puts you in the same vulnerable position as the creature. Sure, the Wumpus is large and cheap, but your opponents might as well have more powerful creatures on their hands. However, I think you may be able to create a deck around this. Just stuff it with powerful fatties such as Verdant Force and Mossbridge Troll. You could also use Crystal Ball and/or Sensei's Divining Top to manipulate the top card of your library.

Not necessarily a bad card if you build around it, and it seems pretty fun in multiplayer. (Also, Rites of Flourishing just as dangerous as this card, if not more so, and it's being rated 4+).

3.5/5

19746: Crumbling Sanctuary.author: The_Murderauder
19746: Crumbling Sanctuary.text_parsed:
In the 2000 World Championship match between Bob Maher and Jon Finkel, Bob made an infamous misplay by casting his Crumbling Sanctuary before attacking with his Phyrexian Processor token when he had Finkel on the ropes. That play eventually cost him the game.


A good reminder that you should be casting most spells post-combat.
