19746: Crumbling Sanctuary.author: Ferlord
19746: Crumbling Sanctuary.text_parsed:
Combo time!

Laboratory Maniac + Volcano Hellion + Crumbling Sanctuary = Mill your deck, kill a possible party pooper (Avatar of Woe, etc)

You'd play Sanctuary first, then you play the Hellion. That way, they won't know why that's happening until it's possibly too late.

You still need to draw, so technically, this is a 3.5-4 piece combo. Not bad at all, considering how bad this could mess up (Like, Naturalize-your-sanctuary-as-you-play-Hellion bad).

Regardless, even without the combo, this is a great card, turning every creature into a Undead Alchemist-aided creature.

19746: Crumbling Sanctuary.author: endersblade
19746: Crumbling Sanctuary.text_parsed:
I run this in Krenko, Mob Boss EDH as an alternate Win-Con. The deck can obviously win by combat damage, but in the off chance that I can't swing (Say, moat in play), I have cards like Kyren Negotiations, Goblin Offensive, and other ways to do direct damage. If I can't deal enough damage to win (say, player has silly amounts of life) then this is the go-to card. Since it exiles, I don't have to worry about normal mill backfires, like Eldrazi preventing a mill win.

This is basically just a great card against decks that can't be killed by damage, for whatever reason. There's really no way to come back from an exiled library.

19748: Magistrate's Scepter.author: Subtle
19748: Magistrate's Scepter.text_parsed:
Coretapper works better with this card than Energy chamber, though I usually run both.

Coretapper, if it is online before the scepter comes into play, can actually instantly get you another turn. Tap once to throw a counter on it, and then sacrifice to take another turn. If you are running Myr Retreivers or Academy Ruins, you can put the tapper on top of your deck again and do it once more.

Sometimes that one extra turn can be what gets your combo off before you go infinite, so jump at the chance!

19748: Magistrate's Scepter.author: Lyoncet
19748: Magistrate's Scepter.text_parsed:
This card has been broken in so many ways I wouldn't be surprised if we saw it hit the banned list sometime soon. If it had been a Legendary Artifact, this would be slightly more balanced, but any combination of one of these and two between Power Conduit and Vedalken Infuser (or three scepters and one of either of those) would give you infinite turns. With how easy it is to tutor artifacts in blue, black, and white, and the addition of Copy Artifact, that's not much tougher to pull off than Time Vault/Voltaic Key.

I recognize that it's not seeing play right now, but in terms of legacy legal cards, it's a pretty quick, simple infinite turn combo. And WotC seems to be really, really sensitive about those.

19748: Magistrate's Scepter.author: UncreativeNameMaker

I think the quickest this could go infinite without ramping is turn 4.

Turn 1: Voltaic Key
Turn 2: Coretapper
Turn 3: Magistrate's Scepter (+1 counter from Coretapper)
Turn 4: Either Coretapper, Voltaic Key, Energy Chamber, or Contagion Clasp (+2 counters from Coretapper + Key)
Turn n: (+2 counters from Coretapper + Key, +1 counter from the turn 4 drop)

19748: Magistrate's Scepter.author: Technetium
19748: Magistrate's Scepter.text_parsed: While not the utterly broken powerhouse that Time Vault is, it's still potentially abused and one of my favorite cards in the game. I play it with Coretappers, Energy Chambers, and Voltaic Keys, along with Copy Artifacts. For a win condition, I use Darksteel Reactor (which just so happens to also take charge counters). Just one or two scepters in the deck is generally all you need, and likewise with the reactors. I use Tinker, Gifts, Intuition, and Tezzeret the Seeker to get what artifacts are missing to make it work. Tezzeret's +1 also enables the combo with just a single coretapper. Supplement with Academy, Urzatron, Seat of Synod, artifact mana, plenty of draw cards (Thirst for Knowledge and Thoughtcast go particularly well here)... so yeah, you can build a fun and sometimes successful infinite turn deck without breaking the bank.
19748: Magistrate's Scepter.text_posted: While not the utterly broken powerhouse that Time Vault is, it's still potentially abused and one of my favorite cards in the game. I play it with Coretappers, Energy Chambers, and Voltaic Keys, along with Copy Artifacts. For a win condition, I use Darksteel Reactor (which just so happens to also take charge counters). Just one or two scepters in the deck is generally all you need, and likewise with the reactors. I use Tinker, Gifts, Intuition, and Tezzeret the Seeker to get what artifacts are missing to make it work. Tezzeret's +1 also enables the combo with just a single coretapper. Supplement with Academy, Urzatron, Seat of Synod, artifact mana, plenty of draw cards (Thirst for Knowledge and Thoughtcast go particularly well here)... so yeah, you can build a fun and sometimes successful infinite turn deck without breaking the bank.

19749: Bargaining Table.author: JovianHomarid
19749: Bargaining Table.text_parsed:
Does it check on resolution?

What happens if my opponent has 4 cards in hand, and I activate this for 4, and this ability goes on the stack. My opponent responds with an instant, and by the time the Table's ability resolves, X=4 but my opponent has 3 cards in hand.

Do I get to draw a card?
19749: Bargaining Table.text_posted:
Does it check on resolution? 

What happens if my opponent has 4 cards in hand, and I activate this for 4, and this ability goes on the stack. My opponent responds with an instant, and by the time the Table's ability resolves, X=4 but my opponent has 3 cards in hand.

Do I get to draw a card?

19749: Bargaining Table.author: Silver-Paladin
19749: Bargaining Table.text_parsed:
@JovianHomarid
You pay X as part of the cost of the ability. It goes on the stack. Your opponent casts an instant, it resolves, then Bargaining Table resolves. Bargaining table's ability says "Draw a card. X is the number of cards in an opponent's hand." You draw a card. The game looks at the second sentence of the ability and shrugs, as the second sentence defines something in the cost, but to the game, since the cost was paid, nothing else about the cost matters.
19749: Bargaining Table.text_posted:
@JovianHomarid

The game looks at the second sentence of the ability and shrugs, as the second sentence defines something in the cost, but to the game, since the cost was paid, nothing else about the cost matters.

19757: Rishadan Pawnshop.author: N03y3D33R
19757: Rishadan Pawnshop.text_parsed:
If you want to hurl a stolen creature into your opponent's library, use the stylus, as it always puts it on the bottom.
If you're running a nonblue deck and need to bounce a permanent that you simply cannot afford to have stolen, then the pawnshop is actually better, since you may redraw that card sometime soon rather than have it sitting on the bottom of your library, Plus you get a shuffle. Very situational, but not totally useless.

19767: Rishadan Port.author: da-odd-templar
19767: Rishadan Port.text_parsed:
Just so people who didn't play back then can understand about this card...

This card was in every deck in Standard. You played Port to tap the opponent's Port, if nothing else. Control decks used it, Fires deck used it, Rebel decks used it.

It really punished multicolored decks, because during the opponent's upkeep you can tap a land they control - if that land is their only source of a color, your uncounterable land just screwed them over, big time. And if you had two (or more) Ports...

It was a very overpowered card, and not fun to play against at all.
19767: Rishadan Port.text_posted:
Just so people who didn't play back then can understand about this card...

This card was in every deck in Standard.  You played Port to tap the opponent's Port, if nothing else.  Control decks used it, Fires deck used it, Rebel decks used it.  

It really punished multicolored decks, because during the opponent's upkeep you can tap a land they control - if that land is their only source of a color, your uncounterable land just screwed them over, big time.  And if you had two (or more) Ports...

It was a very overpowered card, and not fun to play against at all.

19767: Rishadan Port.text_posted: This is the land of lands. I ran 4 of these in EVERY deck I built. It annoys my opponents just as if it were [autocard]Strip Mine[/autocard]s.

19767: Rishadan Port.author: achilleselbow
19767: Rishadan Port.text_parsed: Yea, I'm still not sure why it's considered so good. I mean, aren't you essentially using two of your lands to lock down one of your opponent's lands? Is the idea that it gave you a fairly effective way to use any leftover mana you had after your turn was done?
19767: Rishadan Port.text_posted: Yea, I'm still not sure why it's considered so good. I mean, aren't you essentially using two of your lands to lock down one of your opponent's lands? Is the idea that it gave you a fairly effective way to use any leftover mana you had after your turn was done?

19767: Rishadan Port.author: djbon2112
19767: Rishadan Port.text_parsed: @achilleselbow: The key is "lock down one of your opponent's lands". Think about it: if you use this during your oponents upkeep, it hurts them, but unless you're playing a deck with lots of instants, it doesn't hurt you. And it carries on: on your next turn, you get to untap everything, but that land on their side is still tapped. Rinse, lather and repeat to make for an annoying game. And as da-odd-templar said, in a time of Multicolour decks (from Invason/Masques standard era, at least), tapping down your opponents one Forest in a three-colour deck can devistate that turn, and having a Port yourself can mean the difference between a decisive win and being crippled by his.
19767: Rishadan Port.text_posted: @achilleselbow: The key is "lock down one of your opponent's lands". Think about it: if you use this during your oponents upkeep, it hurts them, but unless you're playing a deck with lots of instants, it doesn't hurt you. And it carries on: on your next turn, you get to untap everything, but that land on their side is still tapped. Rinse, lather and repeat to make for an annoying game. And as da-odd-templar said, in a time of Multicolour decks (from Invason/Masques standard era, at least), tapping down your opponents one Forest in a three-colour deck can devistate that turn, and having a Port yourself can mean the difference between a decisive win and being crippled by his.

19767: Rishadan Port.author: CuriousThing

19767: Rishadan Port.text_posted: A thought exercise for the naysayers: imagine this in Standard today. Imagine tapping a [autocard]Kessig Wolf Run[/autocard]. Imagine tapping a [autocard]Gavony Township[/autocard]. Imagine tapping an [autocard]Inkmoth Nexus[/autocard]. Pretty good, no?

19767: Rishadan Port.author: deadapult13
19767: Rishadan Port.text_parsed: @Solarcanix.  I don't know what Magic you've been playing, but I'm pretty sure than mana pools empty at the end of each step and phase.  If your opponent taps their land in response to the Port during their upkeep, the mana is gone by the time they draw a card.  This pretty much means that the only thing you could use that mana (colored or colorless) for would be an instant.
19767: Rishadan Port.text_posted: @Solarcanix.  I don't know what Magic you've been playing, but I'm pretty sure than mana pools empty at the end of each step and phase.  If your opponent taps their land in response to the Port during their upkeep, the mana is gone by the time they draw a card.  This pretty much means that the only thing you could use that mana (colored or colorless) for would be an instant.

19767: Rishadan Port.author: Solarcanix
19767: Rishadan Port.text_parsed:
@deadapult
Thanks for the rule instruction. I only play casual games with friends, so I was unaware that unused mana empties during each phase rather than at the end of turn. Knowing this will change my rating of this card as well as my future tactics in the game. Thanks again.

The argument was made that this card was good because it was able to tap an opponents land during his upkeep, causing that land not to be available for his use which might hurt in a multicolored deck. Wouldn't the opponent be able to tap that land in response to the port trying to tap it? Sure, the opponent might not be able to use that color anyway, but he could use it to pay any colorless cost at least. At most, the opponent would be able to use the color to cast something. Even if he couldn't use that mana, now with mana burn gone, he isn't out anything because the land would've been tapped anyway. Still not getting why this land is considered good, other than of course it's effect on Maze of Ith, any creature lands, or lands with special abilities. Maybe I'm missing something here, so please forgive my ignorance.

19767: Rishadan Port.author: Enchantment_Removal
19767: Rishadan Port.text_parsed:
I will gladly accept the honor of clearing up the confusion between jimbob (Rishadan Port is not impressive) and everyone else (Rishadan Port is awesome).

First off, there are important things to consider when examining this card. Jimbob expressed confusion as to why this card is worth upwards to $40. Well, tournaments offer prizes to winners- often booster packs- and as we all know booster packs cost real money. So cards that are involved in winning a tournament are real assets.

A person who doesn't play in tournaments has little reason to put a price tag on cards. Most of the time cards are either worthless or priceless (like my very first Islands)

So why is Rishadan Port so good in tournaments? I will have to explain two things to answer this question.
In Magic, especially in tournaments, the definition of "winner" and "loser" is 100% clear. Other games sometimes have multiple goals that players can reach. For instance, in Super Smash Bros. Melee (a fighting video game), the game keeps track of how many kills a player gets, what kinds of bonuses a player gets, and who is the last player standing. While the game does pick a winner based on what mode is being played, the title of "winner" can still be debated- somewhat (bear with me). In casual Magic games, some players are only concerned with executing a certain play (playing a certain good card or doing some high amount of damage) and not so much concerned with being the last player alive- and therefore being the winner.
One thing that turns people off about tournaments is that winning- according to Magic's definition- is the ONLY thing that matters PERIOD. This is a matter of very clear criteria: Which player's life total went below 1 first? Which player got more than 9 poison counters first? Which player was required to draw a card from an empty library first? Which player was affected by a spell or ability that forced them to win or lose the game? Yesterday I played a funny game against someone; both of us were using weird Proliferate decks. I won the game by poising my opponent to death. I was at 9 poison counters when I won. Had I not destroyed my opponent's Throne of Geth the turn before I won, then he could have sacrificed another artifact to the throne at the end of my turn and then the throne itself during his turn, which would've killed me. One tiny detail decided the game and you know what? In tournaments, most games are decided on the most small details. If you don't play in tournaments, then most games you see and experience are probably not close- at the point when the game is over, the winning player has 16 or more life with a full board of creatures and the losing player has only one creature. This leads me to my second point.
In tournaments, players do in fact LOSE because of the ONE TURN where that ONE PARTICULAR LAND they control was NOT UNTAPPED at the beginning of their precombat main phase. Also, in tournaments, a players chances of winning are HEAVILY affected by that player having exactly the mana they need precisely when they need it. Think about it: since when did you have 7 mana out and the Stormtide Leviathan in your hand spoke to you and said "Oh, well even though I cost 8 mana, I can spot you the 1 mana and come into play anyways", or, "Hey it's cool. I see you have 8 lands out even though only 7 of it is untapped right now because one of your land got tapped during your upkeep and, well, that one mana emptied from your pool.... it's cool dude. I understand your situation. That one mana is one the house".
This statement demonstrates two things: The more obvious point that tapping your opponent's lands can be useful, and the less obvious point that YOU need the mana you need when you need it. Rishadan Port contributes to both of these strategies. That is called versatility. You know what else? Rishadan Port does not cost any mana to play. As a matter of fact, it can produce a mana for you the very turn that it comes into play. It also can't be countered.

Lands are so important to 99% of every players' game plan. They are the back bone of our decks. Each land counts. Merely producing mana seems like an insignificant task. On the contrary, being able to make mana without using mana is broken as hell. So if a land makes mana for free AND does something else, then that land has gone far above and beyond the call of duty.

19767: Rishadan Port.author: jimbob123432
19767: Rishadan Port.text_parsed:
@Enchantment_Removal: Okay, I get it, it's good in tournaments, but I still don't buy that argument for it being so expensive. Also, I PLAY IN TOURNAMENTS. In fact, I used to play in Masques tournaments, and I know it was good back then. But the argument of "it won tournaments" doesn't fly with me. Craw Giant used to win tournaments (trample and rampage 2!!). I've won tournaments with Ixidron, Sanctuary Cat, Trepanation Blade, Hellrider, Iona, Konda; and none of these cards are as expensive as Rishadan Port. People in my local card shops have tried to defend this too and I've always countered with either "I play a land" or "I destroy/exile/bounce Rishadan Port". If your deck relies so heavily on 1 land, it's time to rethink the deck. In my opinion, you've got to have more than 1 win condition and more than 1 way to achieve a win condition.
For example: I play a Forest and get a Sol Ring out on turn 1 (before you're able to activate Port). I then play a dual land (which you tap with the Port probably) and then I play a Lotus Cobra, effectively ending your plan. Or, if I'm playing green, I ramp way too fast for Port to matter. If I'm playing red, I blow it up. Blue? I Stifle/Squelch/Twiddle it. Black? Can't really do anything about it, but if I'm running mono-black I probably don't care (unless I'm running Cabal Coffers). White? O-Ring. Sure, I waste a card, but your "super-important land" is gone. If you want to bring up tournaments being won/lost by 1 land, maybe you shouldn't be making your land a target.
Sure, there are CERTAIN SITUATIONS where this is useful, but not enough to warrant a $40 price tag.


I really don't get why people keep praising this card. You're tapping TWO mana to lock down ONE land. There are only a couple situations in which this would be good. First, if it's in set, because Masques was slow. Second, if it's a double land (ie: Orhzov Basillica). Third, if they are EXTREMELY mana starved. Now, what I don't get it that there are BETTER cards for all of these!

Early Frost taps 3 lands. Enervate taps a land and you draw a card. Icy Manipulator taps a land too, even if it's late game (oh wait, Sol Ring is so prevalent that it doesn't matter) and it can tap mana rocks, which are more prevalent nowadays. Mana Short taps all a player's lands. Mind Games taps a land. Mistbind Clique taps all lands and it's a creature. Mole Worms locks down a land. Opposition makes all your lands tap other lands. Reality Ripple phases out a land. Ring of Gix taps a land. Twiddle taps a land. Vedalken Certarch taps a land.

Basically, in the games I play, I don't see how a land like this is "so O.P." and is still $40. Mana rocks are more prevalent and this can't tap artifacts, so the "mana screw/colour screw" argument just doesn't work for me. Manalith, Signets, Sol Ring, Cameos, Diamonds (even though they're pretty bad), Moxes, Mana Myrs, Attendants, Ramos parts, Borderposts, Lotus parts (or Lotus itself), Mana/Milikin, Eggs, Obelisks, and Talismans are ALL commonly run in Extended/Vintage, so Rishadan port is pretty useless in my opinion. It WAS good, but it's not that great now.

19767: Rishadan Port.author: DarthParallax
19767: Rishadan Port.text_parsed:
jimbob123432-- here's the first and most important part of the argument: It's a LAND, not a spell. All the cards you named that are 'better' than this card are spells. This costs no mana whatsoever to put down, and you can choose whether or not to activate it. For some "Utility Lands", as they're called, like Maze of Ith, you never even have to activate them, you just have the threat of them and they're used as deterrence. That type of move is much more common in multi-player, but some cards (again, Maze of Ith) are so good that you can effectively use deterrence in a 2-player game.

The second most important part of this card is super closely related to the first- it hits lands. It IS a land. It is its own best counter. It costs 0 resources to put down initially, and once you do, you are safe if your opponent has it. In some ways, this is a lot like the relationship Jace Beleren has to Jace, the Mind Sculptor, except that you want to play your Port first before the other guy, and you want to be the second guy to play a Jace so you can destroy their Big Jace with your Little Jace. On top of that, Rishadan Port doesn't just say 'tap target Rishadan Port'- it hits ANY. LAND. Any Land. For example those Maze of Iths I keep banging about. Or maybe it's an Urzatron piece. Or maybe Tolarian Academy. Or maybe who knows what. Rishadan Port is second only to Strip Mine in land disruption.

The fact that all lands are 0-drops is something which can't be understated enough, and it's part of why I think every 0-drop artifact ever, even the outdated 'bad' ones are completely viable in Kitchen Table decks against more 'serious' cards. It's also why some of the most incredible cards IN THE GAME are lands. Utility Lands like Maze of Ith, Manaproducers like Tolarian Academy, even Damage Sources on Lands are not to be overlooked. Shivan Gorge is no Grim Lavamancer sure, but it's legitimately good enough for multiplayer to make the cut. A spell that costs 2R that hits each player for 1, even at Instant Speed and uncounterable, would NOT be good enough.

Lands are not only 0-drops, they are REUSEABLE (most of the time). Let me think of the most powerful spells I can think of....Ancestral Recall and Time Walk. Devastating effects, insanely undercosted. You really want to counter these spells if you can. If you don't, your opponent gets something absolutely nuts...once. Then the cards go to the graveyard. Sure, they might have recursion in their deck, but the cards don't actually have flashback or buyback printed on them. Lands are spells that have buyback/flashback forever, at no further cost other than untapping, and they continue to do what you what them to do until they're destroyed. The activation cost on a land should be thought of as the buyback cost on a spell.

Being a 0-drop is good, and every 0-drop non-land card in the Modern frame is just awesome. So there is never going to be a comparison between a spell and a land over a similar effect. Put it on a land and the card becomes much stronger. Now yes, you should never ever EVER base your deck on being 'all about one great card'- but that doesn't mean 'don't put a great card in your deck'. If a card is great, use it.

Now evaluating the ability itself: well, everyone else does that all through the comments section here. I wanted to emphasize, for people that didn't think about it yet, how significant the difference is between lands and spells. It all boils down to this:

A) Lands are important
B) Utility Lands are GREAT
C) This is one of the best things to mess with both A and B, AND one of the best things to mess with ITSELF, which is a crucial point for metagaming. Pretty much targetting anything other than a Basic Land ought to yield good results, and targetting Island is, of course, always worth it. ;)

19767: Rishadan Port.author: Cyberium
19767: Rishadan Port.text_parsed:
Like many great cards, Rishadan Port is a hidden gem till people realized how powerful it is, so much so that cards in the set after it came out has to make new cards to hose it.

- If you play aggro and faces control, you can tap opponent's blue mana at the end of their turn, ensure they don't have the mana to counter your spell.
- You can tap man-land.
- You can tap any utility land your opponent plays such as Library of Alexandria, Maze of Ith, etc, to prevent them from being used freely.
- Cheaper than Icy Manipulator with Winter Orb combo.
- Being a land (hence non-spell), there's very few way to hinter the Port.
- Many, many more.
19767: Rishadan Port.text_posted:
Like many great cards, Rishadan Port is a hidden gem till people realized how powerful it is, so much so that cards in the set after it came out has to make new cards to hose it.

- If you play aggro and faces control, you can tap opponent's blue mana at the end of their turn, ensure they don't have the mana to counter your spell.
- You can tap man-land.
- You can tap any utility land your opponent plays such as Library of Alexandria, Maze of Ith, etc, to prevent them from being used freely.
- Cheaper than Icy Manipulator with Winter Orb combo.
- Being a land (hence non-spell), there's very few way to hinter the Port.
- Many, many more.

19767: Rishadan Port.author: azure_drake222222
19767: Rishadan Port.text_parsed: Best against Sorrow's Path.
19767: Rishadan Port.text_posted: Best against [autocard]Sorrow's Path[/autocard].

19767: Rishadan Port.author: Technetium
19767: Rishadan Port.text_parsed: They work in many decks, but none better than blue control. General strategy is, always reserve mana for counterspells in your hand, then play important cards if you have them, then lock down opponent's lands during their turn with ports. Why use a counterspell on their card this turn if you can prevent them from casting it entirely and save the counter for another turn?
19767: Rishadan Port.text_posted: They work in many decks, but none better than blue control. General strategy is, always reserve mana for counterspells in your hand, then play important cards if you have them, then lock down opponent's lands during their turn with ports. Why use a counterspell on their card [i]this turn[/i] if you can prevent them from casting it entirely and save the counter for another turn?

19767: Rishadan Port.author: Aquillion
19767: Rishadan Port.text_parsed: "Hey, I've got an idea! We're trying to lower the power level of the game after the overpowered Urza's block, right? So let's do this. Let's reprint strip mine, but make it cost a mana each turn to keep the target land locked. What can possibly go wrong? One mana will make strip mine balanced, right?"

Let's [i]reprint [autocard]strip mine[/autocard][/i], but make it cost a mana each turn to keep the target land locked.  What can possibly go wrong?  One mana will make strip mine balanced, right?"

-> No -> Why not?

19767: Rishadan Port.author: Yukikah
19767: Rishadan Port.text_parsed: Really you just have to be smart with this card;  Weigh the benefits of tapping out a certain land of opponent's at a certain time against using two less mana on your turn to cast spells, whether that be on your next turn or holding out from your last turn and using the Port on your opponent's turn.  There are a lot of situations it'll be worth the slow-down in tempo, but obviously you don't use it every turn on just any land.

19767: Rishadan Port.author: Drewskithelegend
19767: Rishadan Port.text_parsed:
Seems like the 2-for-1 only really matters if you are behind. If you make your land drops every turn and happen to be on the play (and your opponent isn't ramping you) then it will always be more profitable to tap them down. Not to mention if they are playing Urzatron, Academy/cradle/Nykthos or wastelands this pretty much levels out the game.
I can't truly appreciate how annoying this card actually is since I haven't played it. I remember playing against a white weenie deck at my first FNM, where the other guy was playing Gideon's lawkeeper and I had virtually no removal spells to cope with them. I can imagine a format where this is legal at 4 to be kinda like that only worse.

You'd need to be running some sort of crazy every color ever deck to make this and all its friends remotely feasible.

19770: Henge Guardian.author: Leshrac_Nightwalker
19770: Henge Guardian.text_parsed:
@Kirbster, Luke_BPC: Agree with both of you.

It's actually too bad... if you're familiar with the Weatherlight saga, you'd know that Gerard et al. headed out to the Henge of Ramos to retrieve some artifacts to help them leave the plane. When they got there, they discovered that Ramos was a huge dragon engine, a relic from the Brothers' War, that had somehow ended up crash-landing in Mercadia - and it was still functioning. Ramos eventually gave the crew his bits (eye, heart, horn, skull and tooth) to help them escape the plane.

Since there are no other artifact dragons in Mercadian Masques, I think it's safe to assume that this card was meant to represent Ramos. That's kind of sad - with so many cards named after him, you'd expect the titular creature to be something more than a 3/4 for .

19772: Dust Bowl.author: Hovercraft
19772: Dust Bowl.text_parsed:
Note, for one thing, the reason this is good over Wasteland or Ghost Quarter is the ability to sac a land other than itself. No other non basic land killing card can do this.
The sacrificed land can be one of the ones you used to activate the '3' ability. So it is basically a Stone Rain, on a stick. I've talked to many people about this land, and I've been surprised how often they miss that. It doesnt need 5 lands including itself in play, needs only 4. So if you're at a sweet spot of 3-4 lands, it works fine. Likewise, Lake of the Dead's second ability effectively taps for 5 mana, not four, you'd have to be silly to not tap the land for mana before sacrificing it . Its got a very generous mana curve for a what is effectively a Wasteland millstone for only 1 more mana than it takes to activate Millstone.

19772: Dust Bowl.author: blurrymadness
19772: Dust Bowl.text_parsed:
Poor man's Wasteland; not bad! (and repeatable! And colorless!)

REALLY good next to Garruk Wildspeaker and anything that increases land drops, primarily Primeval Titan, Veteran Explorer, and Viridian Emissary. One can even tutor this with the titan. By the time you hit 6 lands (including this) you can nab 2 of their lands per turn between your little guys or the titan.

Very quickly gain board advantage. Be sure to sac your non-basics to this so your opponent can't retaliate with Wasteland; not that they should want to at that point.

19776: Wishmonger.text_parsed:
Wow! It's funny to see that instead of changing the creature types of this cycle, they kept them as Mongers - and in 4 out of 5 cases, ADDED a creature type to each!

All of the mongers are pretty awesome for multiplayer enthusiasts, but this one is especially interesting from a diplomatic point of view - if you tap out to cast it, it's entirely possible that one opponent might pay to save this guy if another opponent tries to pull a fast one with removal!
19776: Wishmonger.text_posted:

19777: Charmed Griffin.author: Worldferno
19777: Charmed Griffin.text_parsed:
I'm hearing a lot of people saying this card is terrible... but really ALL it takes is a hive-mind on field, a cackling counterpart, and having the field empty of anything except this creature and BAM insta-cheat in for your omniscience.

What's that? There are easier ways to cheat in enchantments you say? True... but how degraded do you think your opening will feel when they find out you used THIS card as the lynch pin in your strategy to defeat them. Sometimes it's not about winning... it's about something more.

Think about that.

19784: Fountain Watch.author: AmericanVigor
19784: Fountain Watch.text_parsed:
One of the most underrated cards in the game.

It enables you to have tons of artifacts and enchantments that your opponents can't touch unless they have a ubiquitous board-wipe (or destroy Fountain Watch).

But, it can be used as part of the following amazing combos:

Fountain Watch + Privileged Position
(creatures, planeswalkers, and lands you control have super shroud, Privileged Position has super shroud, artifacts and enchantments have shroud)

Fountain Watch + Asceticism
(creatures you control have super shroud, artifacts and enchantments you control have shroud)

Fountain Watch + (Privileged Position or Asceticism) + Worship
(amazing)

Fountain Watch is definitely a 5/5, and a welcome part of my regular gameplay.

19789: Arrest.author: nerothewizard
19789: Arrest.text_parsed:
RANDOM CARD REVIEW - 12-13-12

Many comparisons can be made between cards like Arrest and cards like Oblivion Ring. On the one hand, Pacifism effects don't actually get rid of a creature; they merely make it useless in combat. On the other hand, if an Arrest is destroyed, that's all that happens; their guy can attack and block again. If an Oblivion Ring is destroyed, however, any of the creature's "enter-the-battlefield" triggers will go off, and the frequency of those triggers is cause for concern. Either card is a good means of removal, but each type has its limitations as well.

On the whole, however, the main draw of cards like Arrest is the fact that they are some of W's most effective removal spells, especially in a limited format. Arrest in particular shines because of its ability to shut down activated abilities. While its cost may not make it feasible in Standard, making a big, annoying creature useless for your opponent is quite satisfying. They may still be able to use the creature for sacrifice effects and the like (something which is not available to them if the creature is under an O-Ring), but the likelihood of that is very low. This is, in general, a good Magic card: It's not a bomb or a piece of a ridiculous combo, but it's certainly far from a dud or a disappointment, and it can even rise to first-pick status in drafts.

This particular printing of Arrest, however, suffers from rather lackluster artwork. As cool as it is to see Orim, the scene itself is quite boring, and the merfolk aren't wearing nearly enough clothing for my tastes. And why is the character in the foreground holding his spear by the blade? That seems incredibly unsafe. My favorite part of this piece of art is probably the background, especially the shark behind the glass; the rest is just "meh."

FINAL SCORE: 3/5

19793: Righteous Indignation.author: majinara
19793: Righteous Indignation.text_parsed:
For this card to be any good...
- you must have small creatures (on big ones the +1/+1 won't make a difference)
- your opponent must be playing red or white (or you must be able to change the color of your opponents creatures, or the color words on this card)
- your opponent must attack with creatures you are willing and able to block
- the difference of p/t between the blocker and blocked must be small enough, to have this card make a difference

Also, bad is that the opponent sees this card in time, unlike some instant pump effect.

19796: Sailmonger.author: N03y3D33R
19796: Sailmonger.text_parsed:
One of the few Mongers who had good in-color support for the block. The mere threat of your Rishadan Pirates (Cutpurse, Footpad, and Brigand) pretty much made sure opponents avoided using the Seafaring She-Monger because you would probably force a sac on them during your second Main Phase to retaliate. And the blue player always had the extra land on the field because they Hoodwinked the opponents land back to their hands every single T2 as a way to get ahead, so they always had the extra mana for the Mongers and Rishadan ports in order to stay ahead.

Masques could be a very cruel set if you didn't have any of the "free spells" like unmask.

I believe he deserves more then just 2.5*.

19799: Saprazzan Legate.author: Tamerlein
19799: Saprazzan Legate.text_parsed:
If this guy was Modern legal, he would definitely be an auto-include in the sideboard of the Merfolk deck I'm designing. Being able to get any creature for free is very strong, ESPECIALLY in a deck that can buff him up very easily. With a few lords out he's a 3/5 with flying for free, which is extremely powerful.

The reason that Aether Vial is so strong in Merfolk decks is because you can play the creatures for free to leave mana up for counterspells and to disrupt your opponents tempo. With the Legate, you don't even need a vial in order to do that!

5/5

19805: Coastal Piracy.author: Mode
19805: Coastal Piracy.text_parsed:
Your Prodigal Sorcerer plan won't work out littleupsman, because unlike Curiosity, this enchantment reads "combat damage", ergo damage that is caused during combat from attacking or blocking creatures...

Nontheless this is a nice enchantment i'd also like to see as a timeshifted green version in a future set...or as blue/green hybrid enchantment.

When used along with creatures who have evasive abilities like flying, or which are ideally unblockable by default, this can provide some joyful card advantage. trample and double strike also work great with this.

Although i wish it was one mana cheaper.

19805: Coastal Piracy.author: jfre81
19805: Coastal Piracy.text_parsed:
Built this (mostly blue) artifact deck with some Myrs and other goodies (such as Tezzeret, Agent of Bolas and Etched Champion, perhaps duplicated by Mirrorworks or Semblance Anvil. Basically the idea is to spam the board with a bunch of cheap artifacts and creatures. I found that I was quickly going through my hand and then spending the rest of the game in topdeck mode. Well, turns out it's pretty good at getting creatures through, if not for massive damage, so in goes Coastal Piracy and it does what it needs to do. Now it's winning games.
You probably need a swarm-type deck like this to make this worth having.

19807: Soothsaying.author: Mr_Hendry
19807: Soothsaying.text_parsed:
An interesting card.

The first ability is very silly but it is the only instance of an activated ability in Magic that allows you to shuffle your library without a tap cost. This is in contrast to Madblind Mountain and Myr Mindservant. I guess you really might want to shuffle your library if your opponent cast something unfortunate like Cruel Fate or Sealed Fate (although the second ability would work equally well to do this unless Sealed Fate had been cast for more than five). What I really want to see is a card that grants benefits for each time you shuffle your library so you can combine this ability in some sort of big awkward combo.

The second ability is clearly the better. It the vast majority of situations this card will be more useful and versatile than the similar Ancestral Knowledge. Likewise, there are few situations when you would rather be playing with a Descendant of Soramaro rather than this card.

19807: Soothsaying.author: Lyoncet
19807: Soothsaying.text_parsed: Pales a bit next to Sensei's Divining Top (little doesn't, in reality), but this is one of the best non-deck-specific permanent 1-drops blue has to offer, and its price tag is around 1% of the Top's. Yeah, the first ability is quite overpriced, but I'm going to go ahead and guess that most of the naysayers would love this card if it only had the second. Plus, it gets better as the game goes on and your mana base comes online, and it gives you an instant-speed return-on-investment for any mana you didn't use to counter or play your own spells. While it doesn't give you straight card advantage, it dose give you the kind of advantage that blue really craves - not number of cards, but getting the right cards at the right moment. I want to find a reason not to give it quite 5/5, but I just can't.

19809: War Tax.author: ropebreezy
19809: War Tax.text_parsed: I'd rather run Propaganda.  A smart opponent will attack first before playing spells, forcing you to spend mana to prevent the attack.  You are then mana-less to cast the usual instants in a blue deck (bounce, counterspells, etc) to counter whatever the opponent has up his sleeve for the rest of the turn.  You don't have this problem with Propaganda, it's a done deal for the rest of the game (until it's destroyed).

19809: War Tax.author: TheMurderousKitten
19809: War Tax.text_parsed: I personally love this card when combined with Oracle en-Vec. You use the Oracle's ability on your turn, forcing your opponent to choose which creatures he wants to send at you on his turn. Then you know how much mana it will cost you to shut him down. You can either decide to just take whatever he is going to throw at you if it is small enough, and use your mana to play spells on your turn, or you can wait until his turn, activate the war tax and prevent his creatures from attacking at all, thereby destroying the designated attackers. And you can do it every turn. This combo removes the biggest downside of this card, which is that you have to save so much of your mana every turn on the chance that your opponent will throw some nasty creature your way. It helps to be able to see the future.
19809: War Tax.text_posted: I personally love this card when combined with [autocard]Oracle en-Vec[/autocard]. 19816: Scandalmonger.author: DrSylvan
19816: Scandalmonger.text_parsed:
Scandalmonger could be the poster child for a Masques-block campaign to be elected worst ever. It's a testament to Magic's enduring appeal that the game survived whole sets themed on letting your opponent decide whether your cards worked or not.

This card is particularly bad because it creates permanently empty hands for all players starting almost the moment it hits the board. Either Player A plays Scandalmonger with extra mana open to wreck the opponent's hand, or the first effect his card has is to let Player B nuke his hand.

Unfun.

@Missile_Penguin: I disagree. Any rumour-spreading scandalmonger is going to have to listen to rumours in order to spread them. I'm sure he'd just as often lend his ear to shady eyepatched informants as whisper those secrets himself.

Further, the boar is the prominent figure of the artwork, and really what makes the image notable. If the eyepatched man WAS supposed to be the scandalmonger, why hide him behind such a strange beast?

And, lastly, that guy does NOT look 3/3.

19816: Scandalmonger.author: MacBizzle

This card is a huge liability. When would you ever want completely free opponent-controlled discard?

If you're really concerned about the opponent actually using Scandalmonger against you, use madness. They won't waste a spark of mana on Scandalmonger and you've essentially got an inverse Azure Mage.

19817: Enslaved Horror.author: Taudisban
19817: Enslaved Horror.text_parsed:
Ok, random card gatherer, I will take this challenge.

Gather Specimens makes the drawback a bonus but it might be hard to pay ten mana in one turn. So, we need some way to cast one of those spells for free or cheap. I'd suggest Elvish Piper, or Omniscience, or Jhoira of the Ghitu but all those cards have better things to be doing. So, I will go with Delay.

Delay has the benefit of also protecting your combo if you get it in multiples. This still effectively makes this a turn 9 play, which does one better than turn ten if you hit every land drop. We can still do better than that. Dimir Signet accelerates us as well as fixing our mana, and Jhoira's Timebug quickens our Delay. Clockspinning also works.

We'll also want things to actually be in our opponent's graveyard, so we can throw in Tome Scour. Going on the suspend theme, Nihilith and Mindstab also work here. Vapor Snag can help make Mindstab more effective and delay an opponent's attack plan.

Final list:

Enslaved Horror x3
Gather Specimens x3
Delay x4
Dimir Signet x3
Jhoira's Timebug x4
Clockspinning x3
Tome Scour x4
Nihilith x4
Mindstab x4
Vapor Snag x4
Island x14
Swamp x10

Despite being the main combo of the deck, I've left Enslaved Horror and Gather Specimens at three each. This is because neither is particularly good on its own. Three is a good number to see the both of them over the course of a game without drawing too many multiples. As for the land base, you probably want a bunch of dual lands, but I'm not about to go recommend you drop 40 bucks for playsets of Watery Grave and Drowned Catacomb just so your Enslaved Horror deck plays better.

19818: Molting Harpy.author: Mode
19818: Molting Harpy.text_parsed:
"A 1-mana Mercenary with flying. And 2 power. But not good outside of Mercenary decks."

@A3Kitsune I'd say it's not a good card inside of Mercenary decks, either.

You don't want to waste your second turn just to potentially let her do two damage to your opponent, do you?
If you want to keep her in your third turn, what are you gonna play with your remaining mana?
Another harpy, so you can pay for both of their upkeep costs on turn four?
Nah, i'd say this Harpy is just about as appealing as her face.

I'd much rather have a Cateran Summons or something completely different in my Mercenary deck.

It should be noted though that, as Kryptnyt said, she does make a good blocker in conjunction with Cateran Persuader. Yet she's definitely not something i'd want to see in my hand. You could say i don't want to draw her attention.
But seeing her getting involved in a b*tchfight and die right after getting dragged out of the library is okay.

19824: Primeval Shambler.author: RaymondKHessel
19824: Primeval Shambler.text_parsed:
I have to admit my liking for this guy. One of the few decent Mercenaries from Masque Block, and a solid card on its own. (As a kid, he was an automatic inclusion in any black deck: "cool art from Chippy and a great late-game beater to dump mana into? Perfect!")

Are there better shades out there? You bet. But Primeval Shambler can measure up in one important way: you don't have to constantly baby-sit him (i.e., keep mana available for pumping on defense). A toughness of 3, higher than most other shades, means he survives most burn and small creature assaults. Yeah, his cmc of 5 is prohibitive (and 5 cmc creatures, particularly in black, need to give you a WHOLE LOT to warrant play), but nostalgia is on his side here. Solid, fun card.
19824: Primeval Shambler.text_posted:
I have to admit my liking for this guy.  One of the few decent Mercenaries from Masque Block, and a solid card on its own.  (As a kid, he was an automatic inclusion in any black deck: "cool art from Chippy and a great late-game beater to dump mana into? Perfect!")  

Are there better shades out there?  You bet.  But Primeval Shambler can measure up in one important way: you don't have to constantly baby-sit him (i.e., keep mana available for pumping on defense).  A toughness of 3, higher than most other shades, means he survives most burn and small creature assaults.  Yeah, his cmc of 5 is prohibitive (and 5 cmc creatures, particularly in black, need to give you a WHOLE LOT to warrant play), but nostalgia is on his side here.  Solid, fun card.

19826: Forced March.author: Kirbster
19826: Forced March.text_parsed:
A lot of people seem to not like this card. Personally, I think it's pretty cool. It works with creatures that have high converted mana costs but you can play cheaply - such as affinity creatures or Avatar of Woe - and can easily brutalize a weenie or token deck. Besides, when has black minded having its own creatures in the graveyard?

Plus, those trees in the art are pretty awesome.

EDIT: Okay, normally I don't do this... but BastianQoU is just so fuckin' daft.
Look - I know Avatar of Woe's converted mana cost stays the same. The idea is that if you play the avatar for two mana, then you can still play Forced March for 7 without killing her, all right? I'm not saying this is super-secret tech for killing one card. You use both together because her CMC remains the same.

The worst part may be that you pretty much went on to repeat my comment. Yes, it's good against "token or weenie decks." Golly, where have we heard that before. Oh, what's that? It leaves your big creatures untouched? Man, this guy's ahead of the curve. Yeah, but watch out, or you'll kill your own Myr Enforcer because you played it for free, right? Oh, and it's not bad if you hit your own creatures. BOLDLY BLAZING NEW TERRITORY.

Seriously, you just made me yell over the Internet at someone. I'm almost as disappointed in you as I am in myself now....

19826: Forced March.author: blurrymadness
19826: Forced March.text_parsed:
Deck dependent whether or not you'd rather run Black Sun's Zenith, Necroplasm, Consume the Meek, etc..

(I won't compare to damnation because it's $20+ a card ;) )

In my opinion BSZ will normally be better because you can screw up board positions regardless of having enough mana to actually kill everything; however they do play to different strategies. Certainly your big expensive creatures here benefit more from this and CtM, same with Necroplasm. BSZ coordinates more with a control strategy and less of a counter-strat to issues your big-creature deck may have.

I'd say that the instant speed on CtM and the fact you're unlikely to be casting this at 4+ puts CtM ahead. Necroplasm also allows one to eliminate tokens the turn it's played and can be dug out any time it's needed. Comboing with Slitherhead is an easy way to ensure you kill what you need, but these of course rely on a graveyard strategy.

Still, a decent 3.5/5 card IMO; though I'd almost never use it over the other options, as it's versatility is harder to build around and less powerful in general.

Reasonable in a Reanimator if you need something in your graveyard in a hurry. Got a fatty in your hand first turn and have the resources to get it from graveyard to play, but not enough to get something from your library to graveyard to play?

Or, you know, use it like how it was supposed to be used. The cantrip bit was cool enough to work in my reanimator deck, card advantage seems less important to me for a deck like that, who's main goal is to get a beat stick out as fast as possible, damn the consequences.

You exile a chump card like a festering goblin, then target yourself with the discard ability to get a fatty in your grave. Admittedly this hurts you on card advantage, but the point of reanimator is to get a big threat out fast enough the opponent cant deal with it.

19831: Black Market.author: CorkBulb
19831: Black Market.text_parsed:
This card used to be risky back with mana burn. Since adding the mana is mandatory, if you have nothing to play you'd get burned. And mono-black cant get rid of it. Now that mana burn is done away with, there is no risk in running this.

Black has plenty of ways to get creatures in graveyards (be it yours or an opponent's) so starting the ramp shouldn't be too hard. Collect some nice counters for a nasty consume spirit finisher.

In multiplayer, this would be great at ramping you to unbelievable power. By the time it's your turn again, you could have 10+ counters on it!

However, 5 is a bit late to start mana accel, unless you play something like good old dark ritual

4/5 w/o mana burn

19832: Cateran Summons.author: RaymondKHessel
19832: Cateran Summons.text_parsed:
Cateran Summons is the perfect expression of how truly bad Mercenaries (and black) were in Masques Block. I play black primarily and as a kid was buying my cards at the tail end of Urza's Block and mostly in Masques Block. After black's excellent showing in Urza, Wizards clearly hobbled the color in the following block (not an aberration, either: see how poorly red did in Urza after its dominance in Rath Block).

Let's be clear: This is a hard tutor for one. It's conditional, yes; limited to a Mercenary creature. But even if you only played a few worthwhile mercenaries in your deck it provides cheap fetching. There's the problem, though: there aren't any worthwhile Mercenaries. For example: I suppose in the late game Primeval Shambler could be ok, but a dozen other shade creatures would be better. And that thought process goes on and on: a decent Mercenary could easily be supplanted by a superior non-Mercenary card. Tutoring is the most powerful game mechanic in Magic, and Cateran Summons is still next to useless.

Rebels got Lin Sivvi, Defiant Hero. Mercenaries got this, a 1 cmc tutor, and that still couldn't make it work.

19832: Cateran Summons.author: OlvynChuru
19832: Cateran Summons.text_parsed:
@RaymondKHessel

"there aren't any worthwhile Mercenaries."

That is absolutely not true. There ARE good Mercenaries (though maybe not in Masques). More importantly, Cateran Summons can search for useful cards with a variety of applications. It can search for removal (Nameless Inversion, Crib Swap), reanimation (Doomed Necromancer), aggressive creatures (Mercenary Knight, Dauthi Mercenary, Chameleon Colossus), or a win condition (Mirror Entity). Because of what it can search for, Cateran Summons is one of the most powerful tutors in the game. 1 mana to search for a useful card and put it straight into your hand is insane.

5/5

Being the nominalization of Intimidate yet granting Fear makes this card bear an unfortunately misleading card name now.

The cost is a bit steep. Although flavorful, I don't feel like triple black was necessary at all - at least with two further colorless mana, so I agree with Kirbster.

Imagine this had a Terror-trigger when it enters:

When Intimidation enters the battlefield, destroy target nonartifact, nonblack creature. It can't be regenerated.

Creatures you control have fear.

19839: Flailing Ogre.author: Ideatog
19839: Flailing Ogre.text_parsed:
No, it doesn't cost your opponent a card to kill it. However, the mana it costs (at least 3) sets them back just as if they had played a card, and they get nothing else out of it. And then of course you might just pay the extra mana and save it. In practice the 'Flailing' creatures operate in a similar manner to Glittering Lion/ Glittering Lynx or Knight of the Holy Nimbus: you opponent has a way to kill it, but the exact timing of when they try is something you can play with, like leaving mana open for a counterspell.

Also, I think all of these could be fun with Mana Echoes and changelings.

19839: Flailing Ogre.author: blurrymadness
19839: Flailing Ogre.text_parsed:
The worst of the three. Flailing soldier is actually somewhat difficult to get rid of because he's above the mana curve and he puts pressure on your opponent (as well as a lot of damage.) This guy being at the curve makes it much easier to counter.

Example:
T1 you drop the soldier, T1 they can't kill it. If you go second, instead it's T1 you drop it, T2 they don't do anything and kill it (potentially at least.)

This guy is instead:
T3 you drop him, t3 or t4 your opponent can kill him without using a card. This is the issue with their difference.


Either way, I run a flailing deck with urza lands and everflowing chalice. Surprisingly, even with those high mana outputs the deck is somewhat difficult to get going lol

19841: Kyren Legate.author: Fanaticmogg
19841: Kyren Legate.text_parsed:
Something to think about: If you're playing against a white aggro deck, there's a good chance that they're going to want to go first. If you know your opponent's going to have the pick in the next game, you can sideboard in these guys safely knowing that your opponent will probably go first and you'll be able to drop it for free on turn 1.

Of course, that's a biiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiit too much strategy for how valueable the card is in a game (answer: not very).

19846: Kyren Negotiations.author: kiseki
19846: Kyren Negotiations.text_parsed:
Do not underestimate the evasion that this gives your creatures. Not needing to attack, and the ability to wait until the end of an opponent's turn is incredible. It may reduce the offensive power of your creatures, but it also allows them all to defend. It serves as a rattle snake effect against would-be attackers on two fronts. Killed creatures get a last hurrah in a board wipe. I've also used it in multiplayer to kill a player at instant speed to counter a game-changing spell.

Untapping with this and Hateflayer is usually game over.
This can also supercharge your Chandra's Spitfire's out of nowhere.
This also keeps creatures safe that would otherwise be required to suicide, like Goblin Assault tokens.

19850: Mercadia's Downfall.author: Aaron_Forsythe
19850: Mercadia's Downfall.text_parsed:
Aaron’s Random Card Comment of the Day #38, 11/17/11

Mercadia’s Downfall? Seriously? Is this some kind of joke? Trust me, the downfalls of Mercadia cannot be summarized on a single card, but I guess we are to assume it was because it controlled too many nonbasic lands. Take that, Tower of the Magistrate and Fountain of Cho!

Cards with names like these are typically reserved for apocalyptic third sets, but the Masques block was unique in that each set took place on a different plane (Mercadia, Rath, and Dominaria), so Mercadian Masques was the first and last time Mercadia was a setting for a Magic expansion.

Heavy-handed nonbasic land hosers are typically meant for constructed play, as they are either too mean or too weak in casual play, but this one didn’t work out in that regard. The card cost for a while during development, which I guess could have been too good--a sort of scaling one-sided Price of Progress under the best cirçumstances. I don’t think the card would have been maindeckable in Urza’s/Masques Standard, even at two mana, as there were lots of powerful monocolored decks at the time. Once Invasion came out and multicolored decks with lots of nonbasic lands were being built, an overly-powerful Mercadia’s Downfall might have deterred people from using the newest cards--a bad goal for sure.

Of course, Masques was meant to be a conscious resetting of the game’s overall power level on the heels of the broken Urza’s block, so it is quite possible that many cards in the set were made worse “just to be safe” or “just because.”

19859: Boa Constrictor.author: GrimjawxRULES
19859: Boa Constrictor.text_parsed:
@SavageBrain89: How exactly does this lose some of its potential under the new damage rules? As Ignaser said, it can still be tapped before the combat damage step.

@TanPaper: Your first assumption would be correct; you tap the Boa Constrictor to give it +3/+3 - the ability doesn't trigger when you attack. Boa Constrictor is meant to be a blocker; your opponent attacks with a creature, you block with Boa Constrictor and tap the Boa in response to the combat damage step to give it +3/+3, making your blocker 6/6. Tapping a creature during combat does not remove it from combat, so even though Boa Constrictor is now tapped, it is still blocking the attacking creature, and it's now a 6/6 as opposed to a 3/3.
19859: Boa Constrictor.text_posted:
@SavageBrain89: How exactly does this lose some of its potential under the new damage rules? As Ignaser said, it can still be tapped before the combat damage step.

@TanPaper: Your first assumption would be correct; you tap the Boa Constrictor to give it +3/+3 - the ability doesn't trigger when you attack. Boa Constrictor is meant to be a blocker; your opponent attacks with a creature, you block with Boa Constrictor and tap the Boa in response to the combat damage step to give it +3/+3, making your blocker 6/6. Tapping a creature during combat does not remove it from combat, so even though Boa Constrictor is now tapped, it is still blocking the attacking creature, and it's now a 6/6 as opposed to a 3/3.

19860: Lumbering Satyr.author: JohnADreams
19860: Lumbering Satyr.text_parsed: Not a great card, but a fun card to build a deck around for multiplayer. There are plenty of non-forest ways to produce (eg Tree of Tales, Llanowar Reborn, etc). There are plenty of ways to turn your opponents lands into forests (eg Mind Bend, Convincing Mirage, Dream Thrush etc). There are some ways to exploit those forests (Jedit Ojanen of Efrava, Erhnam Djinn). Not a card I would play competitively, but it makes a real fun junk deck for multiplayer.

19860: Lumbering Satyr.author: Leshrac_Nightwalker
19860: Lumbering Satyr.text_parsed:
Willow Satyr is a Satyr.

This, though... Mercadian Masques had a weird little mini-theme of taking random beasts (to judge by art) and naming them after traditional fantasy creatures that they didn't resemble in the least. Look at Horned Troll for an even greater disparity between what it's named and what the art appears to be showing... WotC even gave it a cheeky flavour text (attributed to Squee) as if to say "This is our game - who are you to question our creative department?"

This guy was only a satyr in name, until presumably someone decided it was more sensible to make the creature type(s) intuitive. I am all in favour of making the game more intuitive, but I don't understand why on earth WotC decided to turn standard fantasy creature tropes on their head for Masques. Changing things just for the sake of making changes doesn't strike me as particularly novel.

As for the creature itself - really efficient, if you are built to handle the rather large drawback!

19860: Lumbering Satyr.author: bay_falconer
19860: Lumbering Satyr.text_parsed:
Hey, look, something that outdoes Aysen Highway in crappitude. While Aysen Highway makes your opponent's guys unblockable iff it also makes your guys unblockable, this guy makes your opponent's guys unblockable and sometimes makes yours unblockable. On a 4/4 body for four mana in the creature color! Why didn't this see play before?

Oh wait, yeah, all the other cards in Mercadian Masques, even Security Detail, are better than this.

Also, satyr? That's not a satyr. A satyr is a man with horns, goat legs, a flute, and a serious case of priapism.

19869: Rushwood Elemental.author: endersblade
19869: Rushwood Elemental.text_parsed:
T1: Llanowar Elves
T2: Garruk's Companion
T3: Leatherback Baloth
T4: Rushwood Elemental
T5: Primalcrux

Without any acceleration other than the Llanowar Elves, a T5 17/17 Trample is nothing to scoff at. Rushwood elemental sweetens the step up with the cost, and will usually be a 5/5 by the time the Primalcrux comes out. This guy really buffed up the damage output in my green stompy deck. I had been running obstinate baloth in that spot to combat any damage loss from early game weenies...but I can typically get the Rushwood out on the same turn as the baloth would, and he serves a better purpose than the baloth as well. In a mono-green deck, I really love creatures that have multi-green symbols in their costs, because they're usually more efficient since they aren't splashable.
19869: Rushwood Elemental.text_posted:

T3: [autocard]Leatherback Baloth[/autocard]
T4: [autocard]Rushwood Elemental[/autocard]
T5: [autocard]Primalcrux[/autocard]

Without any acceleration other than the Llanowar Elves, a T5 17/17 Trample is nothing to scoff at.  Rushwood elemental sweetens the step up with the [G][G][G][G][G] cost, and will usually be a 5/5 by the time the Primalcrux comes out.  This guy really buffed up the damage output in my green stompy deck.  I had been running [autocard]obstinate baloth[/autocard] in that spot to combat any damage loss from early game weenies...but I can typically get the Rushwood out on the same turn as the baloth would, and he serves a better purpose than the baloth as well.  In a mono-green deck, I really love creatures that have multi-green symbols in their costs, because they're usually more efficient since they aren't splashable.

19873: Clear the Land.author: Ragamander

I just saw this card for the first time a couple days ago, and it is definitely going in a Scouting Trek deck! That is some of the silliest land ramp I've ever seen. I might have to throw in an Allosaurus Rider too! Or heaven forbid I use landfall triggers! If not Scouting Trek, then perhaps Lodestone Bauble and some land-sacrifice engine, like Lotus Vale, Army Ants/Tectonic Break, or Squandered Resources (and perhaps a crazy combo involving Overlaid Terrain). Or you could just keep an eye on the top of your opponent's library with cards like Natural Selection, Visions, and Second Sight.

Also, though harder to abuse, it is cool that this will also put nonbasic lands into play.

@Qazior: You exile the other revealed cards, not your other lands.

19878: Monkey Cage.author: DrWorm
19878: Monkey Cage.text_parsed: Okay, so this is my favorite magic card ever.  It is a nice combat trick as a response to any creature played, as it will almost always result in advantage.  When you build a combo deck around it the look on you opponent's face when you swing for the win with, say, 11 2/2 Ape (I call them Monkey) tokens is great.  Give them all flying and wallow in the cinematic reference.

19878: Monkey Cage.author: nammertime
19878: Monkey Cage.text_parsed:
Combat trick? According to the text, you're forced to sacrifice it the next time a creature comes into play. You don't have a choice. What if someone plays a 1-drop 1/1 creature? You just paid 5 mana for a 2/2 creature!

You want to play a creature to use this? You'll have to use a bunch of mana to summon your own creature right after you play this, and honestly here, if you had 11 mana to spend on a Darksteel Colossus and 5 more to spend on this beforehand, you should already have won the game.

At best, it prevents your opponent from summoning something big for a little while, 'til you're forced to use this with your own creature, or you're forced to use it with one of his weenies. This card stinks.

19878: Monkey Cage.author: EggShen
19878: Monkey Cage.text_parsed:
You can get pretty good use out of it if you're cheating fatties into play via something like an Elvish Piper or a Dragon Arch.

Maybe something like a turn 1 Llanowar Elf into a turn two Fierce Empath to tutor up a Draco. Turn 3 Elvish Piper, turn 4 whatever, turn 5 Monkey Cage, then wait for the fun surprise factor. Hopefully your opponent will put out some cheap critter to pop your cage, & in response you activate your Piper, bringing Draco into play and netting a cool 16 monkeys. Turn 6, swing for the win. . . after casting a Coat of Arms of course.

Obviously that requires a perfect draw and not missing a land drop. Still, seems like a fun card in the right sort of deck.

19878: Monkey Cage.author: Kirbster
19878: Monkey Cage.text_parsed:
People seem to be trying to find the easiest way to follow Monkey Cage up with a fattie. But why settle for one? The sacrifice is triggered when a creature comes into play - so do a bunch at once and each one will trigger the cage. If you can drop Twilight's Call with a Monkey Cage out, you could find yourself with 50-odd Ape tokens.

Welcome to the Monkey House, indeed.

19881: Puffer Extract.author: majinara
19881: Puffer Extract.text_parsed:
It's not that bad for Commander I think. The commander damage rule is very relevant there (if you are dealt 21 or more damage from a single commander, you lose), so the puffer extract can be a big help in getting there.
It also can be used on indestructible or regenerating creatures without much of a drawback. Or you can tap it just for 0 mana, to kill creatures an opponent would want to steal from you, or that you stole for a turn, or to trigger "whenever this/a creature dies" abilities. Or when your commander is unable to do something because of an aura or whatever, you can use this to kill him and replay him. And so on.

This card is a bear to fight against.
It is very hard to block effectively, and can turn any medium to high power creature into a monster.

19888: Power Matrix.author: Brawler_1337
19888: Power Matrix.text_parsed:
One of my friends found a Japanese copy of this in a dollar rare box, and he's used it in most of the EDH decks he's built since finding it. Most people don't believe him when he tells them what it does.

I recently bought a copy myself, and I'm trying to figure out a good deck to put it in. It seems like an awesome card to use in EDH. I mean, it can be used for defense, it can be used for offense, it can be used at instant speed, and the extra +1/+1 can make a difference in combat. I really don't see why this doesn't see more play in EDH.

19891: Saprazzan Cove.author: leomistico
19891: Saprazzan Cove.text_parsed:
May I ask for a version of this kind of storage land that comes into battlefield untapped, or something like this:

Tap: Add {1}
Tap: Add 1 counter
{1}: Remove X counters...

However, I quite like this version nonetheless. It can be abused with proliferate or some untap effect like Tidewater Minion or Ral Zarek (it's a kind of effect that seems quite uncommon, actually...)

4/5

Edit: @ patronofthesound:
mirrodin's core
Not quite the same but much better

Except it's not better: it's totally another thing. Mirrodin's core is useful for mana fixing, but it can't store counters to ramp. Two different uses. I'm not saying that Mirrodin's core is a bad card, I'm saying that it's not what I'm looking for...

One day, I would really like to see the Time Spiral storage land (Dreadship Reef and the like), but in enemy-color pair!

19895: Rushwood Grove.author: TDL
19895: Rushwood Grove.text_parsed:
Considering that not everyone can shell out upwards of $200 for playsets of Vindicate and Gaea's Cradle, I think this card is all right.
Anyone can concoct a situation in which a card's weaknesses are blatantly exploited, and setting up a comparison between a common land and a rare, legendary one from a set filled with notoriously powerful cards doesn't make for much of a contest. Yes. The $40 Cradle is generally superior to 0.30$ Rushwood Grove.
A better argument against this card being all that useful is the fact that Rain of Tears was in the same set.
In my opinion, this kind of card is at its best in EDH, where land destruction isn't too common and what there is of it will probably be aimed at other, more powerful lands.

19895: Rushwood Grove.author: UnknownRat
19895: Rushwood Grove.text_parsed: The problem I have with the Mercadian storage lands is they enter tapped (same issue with the Fallen Empires ones too). This means, at best, it takes X+2 turns to get X mana out of one of these things, compared to a Forest which gives you X mana in X turns (albeit not all at once). In my experience, even in slow formats like Commander or Limited, it's very rare that you'd want a big influx of mana late in the game, especially since you typically have quite a few regular lands by that point. The fact that the Time Spiral storage lands A) don't enter tapped B) produce two colors C) can tap for colorless is proof enough to my mind that the designers recognize these old storage lands were nearly useless. It would help in a deck whose major win condition was an X-spell, but beyond that you're almost always better off with a Forest.

20454: Hoodwink.author: N03y3D33R
20454: Hoodwink.text_parsed:
Fantastic Tempo damage from back in the day.
Sure it's mostly obsoleted by Into the Roil, but it's still a good card simply because it's one of the few land bounces. Here's an example of how helpful it can be:

You have your T1 and drop a Phantasmal Bear, end turn.

They have their T1 and drop a land.

Your turn again, drop another Island, Hoodwink their land and swing with the bear.

They have to play their Land again.

Your turn again, you have 3 Lands and they only have one, you are in prime condition to counter their spells using even a basic 3 mana counterspell, and you swing with your bear.

20456: Charisma.author: DoctorKenneth
20456: Charisma.text_parsed:
Mmm-mm, flavour. I love that the creature has to slap the enemy creature across the face a bit before it decides to switch sides. I can almost hear my creatures scream "Snap out of it, man!" Better yet:

"Sir, the black mage's Wumpus should be just through here- ah, I see it, Commander!"
"Yes, it seems to be trapped in some sort of mudhole. It's thrashing about."
"Should...should we attack it?"
"No...no. Just...look at it's fat jiggle. I....I can't seem to look away. It's so beautiful."
"Sir?"
"Come on, boys. We're marching back to camp and burning it down. I haven't seen a jiggle like that in ten fortnights. That beast has moxie!"
"Is the commander going to be okay?"
"This is nothing. You should have seen him when we found those ants. Said they 'bit him just right.'"

Even in a Pandemonium/Primal Forcemage/Fling Deck I'd rather use Blitz Hellion to be honest. Pangosaur would've needed haste to be truly useful to such a deck, but that would've probably been broken and out of color.
Maybe you could use it with Fires of Yavimaya, but then you could just play the Hellion and some more haste creatures instead and save yourself some hassle.

Maybe this would be interesting if you could stop your opponent from playing lands (with something like Territorial Dispute). But even then, I think it still is not worth the trouble. After all, it's just a 6/6 for 4 mana without any decent abilities.

I give it 2/5, at least it's a card that makes you think.

20844: Mercadian Atlas.author: majinara
20844: Mercadian Atlas.text_parsed:
In general I like cards that work automatically without requiring additional mana or anything once in play. And if they draw me cards: even better.

About the effectiveness: I guess it becomes good if you have a lot of land fetchers in your deck. Such as harrow or terramorphic expanse. If in the average deck you have 40% lands, then this has a 60% chance of drawing you cards. Though of course drawing you cards, it increases the chance for you to draw lands. With enough land fetchers, the chance of this drawing you cards can go up to like 80% or 90% or something.

It's also good if you have lands for other purposes in there. Such as trade routes or seismic assault. Or cycling lands, that you don't intent to play unless you're in the first few turns (when this card ain't out). And of course if you have ways to cheat lands into play, this card is fun too. Or it's nice when you have a lot of extra turn spells.

It obviously gets worse if it doesn't have any synergies with your deck. All in all, I give it a 3.5 of 5.

20848: Ramosian Commander.author: themlsna
20848: Ramosian Commander.text_parsed: The rebel mechanic always seemed strange to me when compared with their mercenary counterparts. With rebels, the strategy is to play them early and search for them on later turns when you had the mana, whereas the mercenaries could only search for others that were weaker then they were. I prefer the mercenaries take, but I can see how this would also be rewarding. Seeing them play against each other is pretty dramatic.
20848: Ramosian Commander.text_posted: The rebel mechanic always seemed strange to me when compared with their mercenary counterparts. With rebels, the strategy is to play them early and search for them on later turns when you had the mana, whereas the mercenaries could only search for others that were weaker then they were. I prefer the mercenaries take, but I can see how this would also be rewarding. Seeing them play against each other is pretty dramatic.

20848: Ramosian Commander.author: Wulfsten
20848: Ramosian Commander.text_parsed: The point with rebels vs. mercenaries in terms of the game mechanic is that rebels have a ramp leading up, as every recruiter looks for rebels with casting cost 1 greater than itself. Mercenaries, on the other hand, only search for creatures with the same CC. That's why the rebel activation costs are higher. It's better to have a ramp than always be recruiting creatures weaker than what you've got.
20848: Ramosian Commander.text_posted: The point with rebels vs. mercenaries in terms of the game mechanic is that rebels have a ramp leading up, as every recruiter looks for rebels with casting cost 1 greater than itself. 21300: Bribery.text_parsed: majinara, you're not thinking. A card isn't balanced just because there are certain situations where the opponent might be able to counter it (brand? what?). That's like the doom blade argument, but less relevant. This card doesn't have a shred of balance. Compare it to mind control. This card costs the same, but allows you to search the opponent's library instead of picking from creatures in play, and it's not an enchantment, so it's far more permanent than mind control. It's objectively unbalanced.

21300: Bribery.author: wstonefi
21300: Bribery.text_parsed:
Definitely the most powerful card in Mercadian Masques, an otherwise mediocre set. For just five mana, you get to seek out and neutralize your opponent's biggest threat... and then beat him in the face with it! At the very worst, it's a two-for-one, since he will be forced to use removal on his own creature. And, as if that weren't enough, you also get to look through his entire library and possibly gain valuable knowledge about which cards you need to be wary of.

In short, this card is completely unbalanced. An easy 5/5 for overpoweredness alone.
21300: Bribery.text_posted:
Definitely the most powerful card in Mercadian Masques, an otherwise mediocre set. At the [i]very worst[/i], it's a two-for-one, since he will be forced to use removal on his own creature. And, as if that weren't enough, you also get to look through his entire library and possibly gain valuable knowledge about which cards you need to be wary of.

In short, this card is completely unbalanced. An easy 5/5 for overpoweredness alone.

21300: Bribery.author: Lord_Ascapelion
21300: Bribery.text_parsed: This card has genuinely increased in power as time went on. Creatures got stronger- MUCH stronger! With things like Eldrazi and other high-price, game winning fatties that are actually worth their mana costs, this card has become more than good- it's cruel. It discourages you from even putting big creatures in your deck in the first place. The rise of EDH lead to its price to skyrocket- it was pretty much a dollar rare 10 years ago. More than anything, this card just FEELS BAD to get hit with. You cringe whenever you see your opponent shove his hand out, demanding your deck. Mean, mean, mean...

21300: Bribery.author: N03y3D33R
21300: Bribery.text_parsed:
What makes this card one of the most potentially devastating control magic variants is that it targets creatures that would otherwise be untargetable due to them not being in play. Casting a Bribery and finding something like Progenitus or Emrakul in their library is unbelievably rewarding because it immediately turns that superior defense against them.

That being said, even without a obviously juicy target to cast, taking control of something with a Sorcery (something blue has an easy time copying and recurring from the graveyard) is always welcome.

22288: Trap Runner.author: _GK
22288: Trap Runner.text_parsed:
How does Trap Runner's ability work with the enchant creature card Venom?

If an unblocked creature is blocked by way of this tap-ability, is it this card (Trap Runner) that is the blocker (why/why-not and who is the blocker)?

Another way to put my question is: When Trap Runner''s ability causes an unblocked attacking creature to become blocked, does Trap Runner destroy the now blocked attacking creature at the end of combat (on the account of the attacking creature becoming successfully blocked by the Venom enchanted Trap Runner)?

Thanks kindly (Have not been a game of magic between me and my friends that we have not bickered over the technicalities of this one- and why/why-not it should be treated one way or the other).

22288: Trap Runner.author: blurrymadness
22288: Trap Runner.text_parsed:
@JackBauer and Jphachy
You could cause two or more to become blocked (via untap effects you could get an indefinite amount.) Her tap ability can occur at any time after attackers have been declared and before combat damage is dealt. You block, then you cause someone else to become blocked.

In other words, Since her ability is not a blocker you don't have to "declare it" at the same time; you just cause something to become blocked. Great against a variety of painful creatures.

3.5 IMO. Usually you'll be better off if you can get fog effects, but they serve a little different purpose. This guy is a fog if you can control the board a bit, reusable and free. Don't have removal? No problem; stall for a bit and that Demon of Death's Gate will just have to watch for a bit.

22288: Trap Runner.author: DiscoSpider
22288: Trap Runner.text_parsed:
@TheExaltedFox

It does work on unblockable creatures (says in her ability). I also agree with you on the debate, people should chill out.

@idgit313

Yes, she can block creatures that require more than one blocker with her ability. She can also block creatures with shadow, flying, fear, or really any ability unless they have shroud, hexproof, protection, trample, or the potential for direct damage like Thorn Elemental (I love that guy). Technically the trample or direct damage creature would be blocked, but it's irrelevant because it goes through anyways.

I think Trap Runner is a great card, sure she costs a bit, but she's a lot of fun to use (and can be quite frustrating to be against). A friend of mine uses her in a W/G deck that is pretty tough to fight.
